object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF PRIMITIVE PROSPECTING FURNACE.
description: This is a model of a primitive form of hearth, used in Japan from the earliest times for the smelting of ores of copper, lead and tin, and is of considerable utility to prospectors in remote districts. The furnace consists of a simple cavity in the ground, lined with a mixture of clay and powdered charcoal. A blowpipe, supplied with air by some sort of bellows, provides a blast for the combustion of the charcoal used for smelting. In using the furnace the previously dried cavity is filled with charcoal, which is piled above it to a height of about 3 in. When the charcoal is alight, and a gentle blast has been started, a layer of ore, previously calcined if rich in sulphur, is spread over its surface, with any flux of quartz or limestone that may be necessary, then another layer of charcoal, and then alternate layers of charge and charcoal until a conical heap has been formed. The blast is increased, and the whole charge gradually sinks down as the charcoal is consumed and the ore is reduced to metal. The blast is then stopped, the slag and unconsumed charcoal removed, and the metal allowed to solidify. The solidified metal is then removed and put aside for subsequent treatment, or is left in the furnace and another charge worked upon it. Inv. 1925-25
interpretation: a primitive form of hearth, used in Japan from the earliest times for the smelting of ores of copper, lead and tin, and is of considerable utility to prospectors in remote districts.

description: (Scale 1 : 8.) Used in 1883 This is a model of a type of primitive furnace used for smelting ores of tin in Japan, in use in 1883, and probably for twenty centuries previously. The furnace consists of a shallow cavity in the ground (see No. 1), lined with a layer of clay and charcoal, about 3 in. thick. A blast of air is supplied to the cavity by a pipe connected to a bellows. The workmen are protected from the heat by a wall of wattlework covered with clay. The well-dried hearth is filled with charcoal, a fire is started, alternate layers of tin ore and charcoal are placed upon it, and a steady blast is maintained. As the tin is reduced it gradually settles down; it is removed by raking aside the unconsumed ore and charcoal, and ladling the metal into clay moulds. A similar, but somewhat larger, furnace was used for smelting copper ores.

object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF ANCIENT IRON BLAST FURNACE
description: This is a sectional model of an old furnace found near Gyalar, in Hungary, and exhibited at Budapest in 1897. It is believed to date back at least a thousand years. The furnace had been cut out of the solid rock and was semi-circular in girth, the front being built up with dressed stones. The furnace was 2 ft. 6 in. in diam. at the chimney, and 1 ft. outside at the bottom of the hearth. The total depth was 5 ft. 3 in. The lower portion of the furnace was lined with refractory material. The blast was introduced through a pipe passing through the lower part of the front wall. The bloom of iron was probably removed through an aperture made at the bottom of this wall, though the original description of the furnace does not state exactly how this was carried out. The furnace was provided with a cover and a charging platform. A mass of iron was found in it.

description: MODEL OF CATALAN FURNACE. (Scale 1 : 20.) Made from drawings prepared in the Museum. Plate I, No. 2, p 12. Made from drawings prepared in the Museum. This model represents a primitive type of hearth for the production of malleable iron, in which the fire is urged by bellows. Districts where this method reached a high development and survived long enough to be technically described were Catalonia, in Spain (hence the name given to the process), and the Pyrenees, where documentary evidence carries the practice back as far as 1293. The furnace represented was in use at Montgaillard, Department of Ariège, in 1834. The building used as the forge was situated where water power was available. The furnace was close beside the main wall of the building and consisted of a rectangular hearth, at the floor level lined with refractory stone, and clay, except at the working side, which was of wrought iron to resist wear. Through the wall projected, at an inclination of about 40 deg., the tuyère, which was made of a piece of copper sheet bent into a conical tube. The end was joined by leather to a goose-neck on a wind chest, supplied with blast by an induced current apparatus known as a “trompe.” This apparatus, which is believed to have been invented in Italy about 1640, consisted of a wooden cistern over two vertical trees or hooped wooden pipes. The top of each is contracted by two flat pieces of wood so that the water falls in a thin stream. Opposite this jet are holes in the trees to admit the induced air. The amount of water flowing in is determined by a lever-controlled wedge in the throat of each pipe. The water is separated from the blast by a baffle and escapes over a water-sealed weir. The pressure obtained was from 1.5 to 2 lb. per sq. in. The blast was remarkably steady, but the entrained water introduced into the furnace was a drawback. The furnace, still red hot, was charged to the tuyère level with fresh charcoal; brown hematite, averaging 45 per cent. metallic iron, was charged, covered to the top with charcoal breeze, and the blast turned on. Fresh charcoal and ore were thrown on and the blast adjusted from time to time. The smelter collected the various pieces of the iron and pushed them towards the centre of the hearth, where he agglomerated them. When it was seen that the iron had begun to burn, the blast was stopped and the bloom withdrawn by the aid of a bar and tongs and subjected to treatment under a helve hammer. The duration of a heat was about 6 hrs. A smelter and one assistant were required. The usual product was 100 kg. of merchant iron from 312 kg. of ore with a consumption of 340 kg. of charcoal.

object_name: MODEL OF A SOUTH WALES BLAST FURNACE
description: (Scale 1 : 12.) This blast furnace at Pen-y-darren Ironworks represents a large example of the construction adopted in South Wales prior to 1850. The furnace was a truncated square pyramid, constructed of massive masonry with an independent lining of firebrick blocks, separated from it by a layer of sand. Four arched openings were left in the base, on one for the fore-hearth and tap-hole and three for tuyères; these were connected by a tunnel conveying the blast main. The ore and fuel were fed in at the open top, through four openings in the tunnel head. The blowing engine supplied blast at a pressure of 2 or 3 lb. per sq. in. to two cold-blast tuyères through leather “goose-necks,” and to the third hot-blast tuyère through a ball-and-socket jointed cast-iron goose-neck. The small pipe stove employed, by which some of the blast was heated to a temperature of 370°C., was arranged at one side; it consisted of nine semicircular cast-iron pipes placed parallel, in a chamber heated by a coal fire. (In the model the roof of the stove is raised several inches to show the arrangement of the pipes.)

description: This represents a blast furnace used at Gwendreath, South Wales, about 1850. The inside shape is roughly that of two truncated cones with their bases together and a hearth of rectangular section below. In three sides of the hearth are inserted the seven tuyères, 1.5 to 2.75 in. diam., and on the fourth is the cinder notch. The furnace was 30 ft. high, 4 ft. sq. at the hearth, 12 ft. diam. at the boshes, and 8 ft. diam. at the throat. The charge to produce 1 ton of pig was: 35 cwt. of anthracite, 45 cwt. of calcined ironstone, and 16 cwt. of limestone; 3,000 cub. ft. of blast at a pressure of 2.25 lb. and temperature of 320° C. were supplied per min.; the output was 105 tons per week.

description: The furnace represented was erected at Blaina Iron Works, South Wales, about 1850. It has a cylindrical shaft on a square base, with three tuyères and the usual cinder-notch and tap-hole. A pair of cast-iron bearers, crossing one another just below the top, carry a cast-iron cup, in which there is placed a perforated wrought-iron tube placed concentrically with the cone, but not quite touching it, and outside slides another tube suspended by flat link chains from an arched lever; the latter, when lowered on to the cone, completely closes the top, and the gases pass away through a rectangular tube, controlled by a butterfly valve, to be utilised.

description: This represents one of the four furnaces at the Cardiff steel works of the Dowlais Iron, Steel & Coal Co., South Wales. The hot blast is admitted through eight tuyères, while above them are four “monkey” tuyères, by which cold blast can be introduced should the charge show any signs of “scaffolding.” The tuyères are cooled by water circulating through wrought-iron pipes cast in their walls, and the boshes of the furnace are cooled by 40 cast-iron blocks, through which water is circulated in the same manner; the cooling water for both is supplied from an annular channel, from which it passes to distributing boxes and regulating cocks. The furnace top is closed by the cup and cone arrangement; the cone or bell is supported by rods from two levers, mounted in bearings on supporting girders, and connected to a linkage that ensures vertical motion. It is counter-balanced and is moved by hand gearing controlled by a brake. When the top of the furnace is closed, the gases pass through the “down-comers” to an underground flue, from which they are led to the hot blast stoves and boilers, where they are burnt. The charge of coke and ore, with limestone to act as a flux, is tipped into the cup out of small barrows, which are raised to the gallery at the furnace top by a hydraulic hoist. When the bell is lowered and the charge enters the furnace, the escaping gas is ignited by a fire kept constantly burning at the top of the furnace so that the poisonous carbon monoxide is converted into the less dangerous carbon dioxide; the charging mechanism is provided with an iron shelter for the protection of the workman. The slag, which floats above the molten metal in the hearth, is run off at intervals into ladles, mounted on railway trucks, which, after being hauled to the slag heap, discharge their loads by side-tipping. The molten metal is tapped at intervals into a sand channel, which leads it to the pig beds, where it is cast into the form of large sows and combs, which, when cooled, are carried to a hydraulic machine by which the pigs and sows are broken into short lengths and discharged into railway trucks. The blast furnace represented is 75 ft. high from the hearth and 85 ft. from the works rail level; the diam. at the hearth is 9 ft., and at the boshes 20 ft.; the output of the furnace is about 1,300 tons of pig iron per week. The blast is heated by Cowper stoves, each 68 ft. high by 24 ft. diam.; three stoves are provided for each furnace, so that, in addition to the pair working alternately, there is a spare one for use when repairs become necessary. On the ground level instruments are provided for recording on paper strips moved by clockwork the temperature of the blast, the times of charging, etc.

object_name: MODEL OF BLAST FURNACE CHARGING APPARATUS
description: The older blast furnaces were erected on hillsides, so that the charges could be wheeled direct to the top. As dimensions increased, improved methods of raising the materials became necessary; the inclined plane was used to some extent, but the vertical hoist is most general in this country and abroad, except where the inclined hoist is used in the latest plants. The arrangement of inclined hoist shown was patented in 1897 by Mr. Stevenson. Under this system each furnace requires a separate hoist, but the outlay is justified with an output of over 150 tons of pig iron a day, as this necessitates the handling of about 500 tons of raw material. Instead of, as usual, filling the charge into barrows and hoisting them to the bell at the top, it is tipped into skips at the ground level. The skips run on rails on the lower flange of the inclined lattice girders, and one ascends while the other descends, being drawn up and lowered by ropes from an engine or electric motor below. When the top is reached a cross-bar on the skip engages in elliptical guides on the under flange of the girders and automatically tips its contents into a hopper. When it is full the bell of the hopper is lowered, permitting the charge to fall into the usual cup and cone arrangement below. When sufficient material has accumulated there, that cone is lowered, and the charge descends into the furnace. These operations can be controlled from the ground level by the lift engineman, requiring no labour at the top. The arrangement gives a good distribution of material in the furnace and prevents escape of gas when lowering the bell.

object_name: MODEL OF MECHANICAL CHARGING APPARATUS FOR IRON BLAST FURNACES
description: This model represents a charging apparatus suitable for furnaces with large outputs. A uniform distribution of the charge and reduction of labour are secured by the use of a mechanical charger of this type. The apparatus consists of an inclined girder tramway on which are two lines of rails, so that the weight of the ascending skip is balanced by that of the descending skip on the other line. These skips carry about 2 tons of ore, and are made of strong sheet-iron. They run on four flanged wheels, of which the two in front are half the thickness of those at the rear. A special guide rail is provided at the top of the furnace, placed so that the narrower front wheels, when descending, pass by it, while the broader hind wheels mount upon the guide, with the result that the back of the skip is lifted up and the charge in the skip is shot into the upper hopper, provided with a small cup and cone. When sufficient material has accumulated in this hopper, the weight of the charge causes the cone to fall, allowing the charge to fall into a gas chamber, which in its turn is also provided with cup and cone discharge of normal dimensions, fitted with a balance weight. A further accumulation of charge in this chamber causes the balance weight to rise, allowing the charge to fall into the furnace. By this means an even distribution of charge in the furnace is obtained, while the loss of gas is reduced to a minimum. The hoist is electrically operated, and is under the entire control of one man.

description: This collection was, in the main, selected from a representative series of iron ores illustrating the resources of Great Britain, prepared for the Exhibition of 1851, under the direction of Mr. S. object_name: SECTIONAL MODELS OF HOT BLAST STOVES
description: (Scale 1: 24.) Mr. E. A. Cowper 1857 / 1882 These two models show the construction of the apparatus patented by Mr. E. A. Cowper in 1857 and subsequently, for utilising the waste gases from blast furnaces to heat the blast; they are a type of “regenerator,” and by their use the consumption of fuel per ton of pig iron produced is greatly diminished. The stoves are arranged in pairs, one stove absorbing heat from the waste gases, while the other is giving off its previously absorbed heat to the blast, the process being reversed at intervals as the stored heat is abstracted. Each stove consists of a vertical shell of wrought iron, to give the strength necessary to resist the pressure of the blast, lined with firebrick, and containing a large vertical passage or “flame flue” built in firebrick. The waste gases are brought in below the base of this chamber and pass up into it through three ports, there mixing with the requisite amount of air for combustion from an air inlet valve. The mass of flame then passes to the top of the stove and returns downward through a large number of small passages built in firebrick, to which the heat is transmitted, the cooled products passing by an underground flue to a chimney. While this is going on the blast for the furnace is being sent through the other stove in the reverse direction, so that the cold blast first meets the coolest part of the stove and passes on to the hottest. The extreme temperatures of the firebrick do not greatly differ during the cycle, the regenerative action depending rather on the extent to which the high temperature zone extends towards the cooler part of the stove, or upon the change in the average temperature of the total amount of firebrick. The stoves are cleared from dust by firing a small gun into an aperture near the base, but it has since been found that by suddenly releasing the pressure in a stove the passages are very effectually cleaned. In one of the models the regenerator brickwork is formed of rectangular bricks on edge, bonded in a way which leaves passages that, while facilitating the absorption of heat, have ledges upon which dust deposits. The other model shows the modification that was introduced by Mr. Cowper in 1882 to avoid this difficulty; special firebrick blocks, known as “honeycomb filling,” are used, which, when fitted together, leave a large number of hexagonal channels that, while easy to clean, present a great amount of heating surface. Two of the actual bricks are shown below the case, one being from the top course, in which the partitions come to an edge.
interpretation: ['These two models show the construction of the apparatus patented by Mr. E. A. Cowper in 1857 and subsequently, for utilising the waste gases from blast furnaces to heat the blast; they are a type of “regenerator,” and by their use the consumption of fuel per ton of pig iron produced is greatly diminished.', 'The stoves are arranged in pairs, one stove absorbing heat from the waste gases, while the other is giving off its previously absorbed heat to the blast, the process being reversed at intervals as the stored heat is abstracted.', 'Each stove consists of a vertical shell of wrought iron, to give the strength necessary to resist the pressure of the blast, lined with firebrick, and containing a large vertical passage or “flame flue” built in firebrick.', 'The waste gases are brought in below the base of this chamber and pass up into it through three ports, there mixing with the requisite amount of air for combustion from an air inlet valve. The mass of flame then passes to the top of the stove and returns downward through a large number of small passages built in firebrick, to which the heat is transmitted, the cooled products passing by an underground flue to a chimney.', 'While this is going on the blast for the furnace is being sent through the other stove in the reverse direction, so that the cold blast first meets the coolest part of the stove and passes on to the hottest.', 'The extreme temperatures of the firebrick do not greatly differ during the cycle, the regenerative action depending rather on the extent to which the high temperature zone extends towards the cooler part of the stove, or upon the change in the average temperature of the total amount of firebrick.', 'The stoves are cleared from dust by firing a small gun into an aperture near the base, but it has since been found that by suddenly releasing the pressure in a stove the passages are very effectually cleaned.', 'In one of the models the regenerator brickwork is formed of rectangular bricks on edge, bonded in a way which leaves passages that, while facilitating the absorption of heat, have ledges upon which dust deposits. The other model shows the modification that was introduced by Mr. Cowper in 1882 to avoid this difficulty; special firebrick blocks, known as “honeycomb filling,” are used, which, when fitted together, leave a large number of hexagonal channels that, while easy to clean, present a great amount of heating surface.']

collection: SECTIONAL MODEL OF HOT BLAST STOVE.
object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF HOT BLAST STOVE.
description: The feature of this form of firebrick stove, patented by Mr. Whitwell in 1865, is that the heated gases are passed through long channels with smooth walls of firebrick, instead of through the shorter, but comparatively more tortuous, passages of the Cowper stove (see No. 13). The waste gas from the blast furnace, used to heat the stove, is burnt in the large vertical combustion chamber on the right-hand side of the stove, sufficient air for the purpose being admitted by a special valve near the base of the stove. The heated products of combustion then pass repeatedly down and up the stove between the partitions, heating them and finally passing to the chimney valve on the extreme left. As in the case of the Cowper form, two stoves at least are necessary, one being heated, whilst the other is heating the blast. Small passages are left in the brickwork for the purpose of inspection and for determining the temperature, while openings in the roof and in the rear of the stove are provided through which dust can be detached from the walls and be removed. The roof of this stove is flat, supported by wrought-iron girders, and is provided with doors for cleaning the vertical passages.

description: (Scale 1: 4.) J. L. Stevenson, Esq. 1898 These represent different forms of bricks for filling the interior of hot blast stoves and for the chambers of regenerative furnaces, patented in 1898 by Mr. Stevenson and Mr. J. Evans. The brick is of a double cruciform section, which leaves square openings when filled in. For hot blast stoves the bricks are laid so as to give uninterrupted square vertical passages, at the same time breaking joint. For regenerative furnaces the bricks are laid so that one layer interrupts the openings in the layer above and below. For a given cubic capacity, the thickness being the same, the square filling has greater heating surface, but less volume, than Cowper's hexagonal section (see No. 13). Inv. 1904-127.

object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF BLAST FURNACE WITH HOT AIR STOVE.
description: (Scale 1 : 16.) Presented by J. P. Budd, Esq. 1828 (demonstration); 1844 (successful arrangement) The economy, due to heating the air supplied to a blast furnace, was first demonstrated in 1828 by Mr. J. B. Neilson at the Clyde Iron Works, where he used a coal-fired stove to heat the blast. Several attempts were subsequently made to attain the same result by utilising the sensible heat of the waste gases, but the first successful arrangement of this kind was that introduced by Mr. Budd in 1844, and fitted to a row of six anthracite furnaces at the Ystalfera Iron Works, South Wales. The model represents one of the furnaces so fitted; it was open-topped, and at about 3 ft. below the top had three or four nearly horizontal flues, about 12 in. diam., leading to a chamber supported on an arch and incorporated in the masonry. This chamber contained a series of upright pipes, connected to cross pipes from the upcast cold blast main on one side and the downcast hot blast main to the tuyères on the other. A chimney, about 25 ft. high, was added to draw off the required amount of gas from the upper part of the furnace, through the chimney, and a small controlling damper on the top of this chimney, and a small door in the stove front for the admission of air when the stove was being cooled for repairs. The waste gases were at a temperature of 982° F., and left the stove at 455° F., heating the blast to 314° F., above which at the time it was considered inadvisable to go. Combustion of the gases was therefore unnecessary.

object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF BLAST FURNACE PLANT.
description: This shows the water-seal method of closing the top of a blast furnace, in order to collect the waste gases. The throat of the furnace is closed by a tube and a cover (shown detached), on which is a cup that can slide on three pillars for charging; when down, the edge dips into an annular water seal. The gases are taken off at opposite sides by two tubes leading to the gas mains, which have water-sealed troughs of water suspended below to catch the dust. Part of the gases are burnt in the heating stove, which consists of a combustion chamber containing several upright pipes with internal radiator cores; the blast is heated by passing through the annular space between them. All the joints are accessible from outside. Another part of the waste gases is used for raising steam. The boilers are of the externally-fired elephant type, with a cylindrical shell above connected to a heater of smaller diameter below. The flame passes from the main shell to the heaters, the course of the feed-water being in the reverse direction.

object_number: MODEL OF THE AYRESOME IRON WORKS
object_name: MODEL OF THE AYRESOME IRON WORKS
description: (Scale 1:96.) Lent by Messrs. Gjers, Mills & Co. 1870 This represents the general arrangement of these iron works, situated on the River Tees at Middlesbrough, built in 1870, and covering an area of 32 acres. The raw materials, in the shape of ironstone, coke, and limestone, are brought in wagons to an inclined road, down which they descend by gravity to a pneumatic hoist, which lifts them to a height of 35 ft. to the gantry passing over the depot and calcining kilns. The ironstone is tipped into these kilns, of which there is a set of four to each pair of furnaces; the coke into two boxes, situated between the sets of kilns; small coal for the kilns into a depot close to the hoist, and the limestone into two bunkers, one at each end of the sets of kilns. The kilns are of the form patented in 1863 by Mr. J. Gjers. Each consists of a shell lined with firebrick, resting on a cast-iron ring, supported on columns, so as to leave an opening at the bottom of the kiln through which the calcined stone is withdrawn. The kilns are 33 ft. high by 24 ft. diam., and are each capable of calcining 1,000 tons of ironstone per week. After being emptied, the wagons run by gravity to the further end of the gantry, where they are lowered to the level by a hoist and despatched to sidings. The ironstone, coke, and limestone, taken from the depots are filled into iron barrows, which, after being weighed, are elevated to the furnace tops by pneumatic hoists, which are made of cast-iron flanged cylinders, 36 in. diam. The furnaces, which are built of brickwork hooped with iron, are 85 ft. high and 25 ft. diam. at the boshes. They are closed with the cup and cone arrangement, the gases being carried through tubes into a culvert below and thence distributed to the stoves and boilers. They are each blown by five tuyères, and are equal to the production of about 2,500 tons of pig iron per week. For each furnace there is one hot blast stove, consisting of 14 double-legged pipes of flat section. The cold blast from the main enters each stove by means of a breeches pipe connected outside, and the hot blast passes out by a similar pipe at the opposite end of the stove, and is delivered into a horseshoe main, which passes round the furnaces. Each stove has an ordinary firegrate to enable firing to be done in case of stoppage, but this grate is closed up when the stove is at work. Twelve egg-ended boilers provide steam for three vertical direct-acting blowing engines, one of which is, however, always held in reserve. They work at 50 lb. steam pressure, and supply the blast at a pressure of from 4.5 to 5 lb. A series of fountains are used to cool the water from the tuyère coils. Specimens of the various numbers of foundry, hæmatite, ferro-silicon, and silico-spiegel-iron made at these works are shown.

description: This is a small cylindrical shaft furnace for remelting pig and scrap iron for the production of castings. It has an iron shell lined with firebrick, and is provided with a charging door, a hood, and a stack. The blast is admitted through two opposite tuyères, but to permit of the accumulation of a large quantity of molten metal when required for a heavy casting, there are three rows of tuyère holes, those not in use being stopped with firebrick plugs. object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF STEWART’S CUPOLA AND RECEIVER
description: This cupola, patented in 1883 by Mr. A. Stewart, has three zones of fusion, diminishing in depth towards the bottom, where the highest temperature is required. The tuyères in the top zone are provided with separate plug valves. The blast is supplied from an annular air-belt, which is divided into two compartments, each being controlled by a stop valve. If the tuyères in one compartment get blocked with slag, they can be cleared by shutting the stop valve in that half and keeping the other open, when the hot gases will blow through and melt the slag in a few moments; by repeating this operation when required, the tuyères can be kept clear without having to punch through with a bar. At the top of the cupola are two damper doors, which can be adjusted to deflect the sparks as desired. The cupola is mounted on pillars carrying a cast-iron drop bottom with wrought-iron hinged doors, which can be dropped after every blow to let out the slag, etc., and keep the brick lining in good working order. To collect the metal as it is melted, a receiver, lined with firebricks, is provided, the top having an air pipe for conveying the hot fumes back again to the cupola. On an average of six tests, 1 lb. of coke, inclusive of bed, melted 13.2 lb. of iron, or 1 cwt. of coke, exclusive of bed, to 19.7 cwt. of iron. The blast was supplied at a pressure of 0.75 lb. per sq. in. A cupola of the size represented is suitable for melting 5 tons of iron per hour.

description: The Lancashire hearth process, the one chiefly employed now in Sweden for making wrought iron, was introduced into that country in 1830 by Gustav Ekman from the Furness district of Lancashire, hence its name ; the process is now extinct in Great Britain. The iron is used for conversion into steel and for ordinary blacksmith’s work. As now built the hearth is rectangular, enclosed by cast-iron plates, with renewable linings. The bottom plate is protected by a layer of slag, and is kept cool by a jacket, into which water is led ; the overflow passes to a drain. Two water-cooled tuyères, one on each side, are supplied with blast at a pressure of 1 to 1.5 lb. per sq. in., warmed to about 180° C. by passing through a U pipe in the waste gas flue. The fore plate, or cast-iron table in front, serves to manipulate the charge. The hearth is filled with fresh charcoal, and the charge, which is in the form of trapezoidal pigs that were in the previous operation pushed through a side door on to a cast-iron plate in the waste gas flue in order to get hot, is now drawn on the top of the charcoal. More charcoal is piled on and the blast is turned on. In about half an hour the metal will have melted and passed through the blast, becoming partially oxidized, till it comes into contact with the basic iron slag on the bottom left from the previous operation. The refining consists in breaking up the metal with a bar and carrying it to the tuyères. The more highly carburised iron, being more fusible, continually drops away till the whole is pasty. The final operation is to bring the lumps of iron to a welding heat with fresh charcoal and make them into a ball. The ball is removed from the furnace, consolidated into a bloom, reheated and rolled into bars. Slag, if present in excess, is tapped out by the holes in front. The whole operation lasts about 70 minutes. In front of the furnace is shown a power-driven rabble, recently introduced to relieve the muscular exertion involved. The overhead shaft, through a clutch and reducing spur gear, drives a connecting rod, which gives partial rotation to a crankshaft, whose bearings are on the furnace front. The bar used for bringing the charge from the bottom of the hearth to the vicinity of the tuyères. has a projection which is caught by the crank as it comes down and forced under the charge. The bar is then manipulated from the fore hearth. Some rabbles have cranks for the latter operation also. The charge consists of about 275 lb. of pig iron; 11.8 cub. ft., equal to about 160 lb., of charcoal is required for refining it. The weight of blooms produced is about 85 per cent. of that of the pig iron charged. S.M. 439.
interpretation: The Lancashire hearth process was chiefly employed in Sweden for making wrought iron. It is now extinct in Great Britain. The iron is used for conversion into steel and for ordinary blacksmith’s work. The model shows the construction and operation of the hearth.

description: (Scale 1: 8.) Wrought iron is obtained from pig iron in the “wet” puddling process by stirring the latter when molten on the bed of a reverberatory furnace with excess of air and in contact with fused oxide of iron, thus oxidising carbon and other impurities. The model represents a furnace used for this process at Bromford Iron Works, South Staffordshire, in 1860. The casing is formed of ribbed cast-iron plates, held together at the top by tie-bolts and at the bottom by a wrought iron trough. The arched roof, sides, and fireplace are made of Stourbridge firebricks. The bed is lined with refractory substances rich in oxide of iron, such as “bull dog.” The grate area, 14 sq. ft., is almost as large as that of the bed. The furnace is fired from a small hole, kept closed by coal piled upon the ledge projecting below it. A fire bridge divides the grate from the hearth, the bed and sides of which are made of cast-iron plates supported on columns and cooled by air circulating beneath. The door is suspended from a lever and is used for “fettling,” charging the pig iron, and for taking out the finished blooms; for the actual puddling there is a small hole at the bottom of the door. Below this is a tap-hole to let out the accumulated slag or “tap cinder” at the end of the operation; normally it is closed with sand. The waste gases are led by a flue to a chimney stack of brick, bound with angles and tie-bolts, and supported on cast-iron columns. It has a damper on the top, by which the heat and the nature of the atmosphere on the hearth are regulated. The charge was 4 cwt. of white iron, which required 1.25 hrs. to work off; 1.25 tons of coal and 1.1 tons of pig iron were required to produce a ton of puddled bars.

object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF IMPROVED PUDDLING FURNACE
description: (Scale 1: 12.) Lent by Jeremiah Head, Esq. 1871 (Patent date) This form of puddling furnace was patented by Mr. Head in 1871. The object of the arrangement is to utilise the heat in the discharged gases, by causing them to heat the air supplied to the furnace grate for the combustion of the fuel. The furnace shown is of the usual construction, having a cast-iron bed lined with oxide and silicate of iron, and the masonry strengthened by external cast-iron plates. The waste gases from the hearth pass into an enlarged or iron-cased stack, carried on columns and terminating in an ordinary stack or iron-cased chimney. The enlarged portion of the stack is divided by a vertical wall into two flues, one of which is clear and passes the gases upwards, unless it should be closed by the horizontal damper moved by rack and pinion; the other chamber also communicates with the stack, but contains cast-iron pipes standing on a divided box. Into one side of the box air is forced by an external steam-jet blower, and this air, in traversing the pipes, is heated to about 340° C.; it then passes along a pipe at the back of the furnace into the closed ashpit. A portion of this heated blast is introduced through tuyères into the space above the fuel, while some is blown downwards upon the fire from orifices in a bridge pipe of brickwork built in the crown. It is stated that the consumption of coal in this furnace averages about 0.63 ton per ton of puddled bar produced, or about one-half of the quantity required by the earlier forms. The steam for the jet may be supplied by a vertical boiler placed in the stack, an alternative arrangement, which is also shown.

description: The furnace is supported by a complete casing of iron plates, the firegrate is large, and the heating rapid. The bed is flat and lined with firebricks set on end, whilst the roof is arched longitudinally; no preparation is made for keeping the bed cool by the circulation of air beneath it, but the fire bridge is protected in this way. The working door is of sufficient size to admit the largest pieces of metal that are to be heated, and beneath the door is an aperture through which the slag, resulting from the action of the iron oxide upon the sand bottom of the furnace, flows away. The door itself is of iron, usually lined with brickwork, and is opened by a lever attached to the framing of the furnace. The chimney stack is supported by four cast-iron columns and an entablature, so that the repairs to the furnace can be executed without interfering with the stack; a damper for controlling the draught is fitted on the top of the stack.

description: This obsolete form of furnace consists of a simple hearth or flat fire, urged by a current of air from a blast pipe inclined downwards. The metal to be refined was placed on a layer of hot coke or charcoal and the blast urged until it was melted; the large excess of air employed caused a great deal of oxidation, so that the silicon in the pig iron was removed and the charge rendered suitable for the puddling furnace in which the carbon was afterwards removed. When the operation had proceeded far enough the refined metal (a kind of "white" pig iron) was run out and cast in a recess provided in the floor between the two refineries. The sides of the hearth were generally formed of water-cooled iron troughs, lined with a layer of slag.

description: This "balling" furnace is used for raising to a welding heat the "piles" built up of puddled bars, previously to hammering or to rolling into merchant iron. It closely resembles the puddling furnace in construction, but has a flat bed made of sand on a course of firebricks, resting on cast-iron plates. The bottom slopes slightly towards the chimney, below which there is a tap-hole for the cinder. The piles are charged on a "peel," and, when heated, are withdrawn by tongs.

object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF FURNACE FOR MALLEABLE IRON CASTINGS
description: The model shows one complete chamber and another chamber in section of a double furnace, arranged in a shallow pit. Each chamber has an arched roof, and a central firebrick platform, upon which the boxes containing the castings to be treated are stacked. Along each side of the platform extends a grate, the heated gases from which, after passing upwards and amongst the annealing boxes to the roof, descend through a flue in the front wall into a larger flue beneath the platform, from which they pass to the stack (not shown), thus giving up some of their heat to the brickwork. The back of each chamber has a large arched opening, which, after the boxes have been placed in position, is bricked up, a loose brick being left to provide for inspection. The furnace walls are supported by vertical "buckstaves," made of old rails tied together above and below by through rods, additional stays being placed at the sides to resist the thrust of the roof arches. The castings to be treated should be as free as possible from sulphur and phosphorus, and as the rate of conversion diminishes gradually as it proceeds inward, thick sections should be avoided; also the process is more successful with small than with large castings. The castings are packed in iron boxes or "saggers" with oxide of iron in the form of powdered red hæmatite, or of scale from the rolling mills. The temperature of the furnace is gradually raised during 24 hrs. to a bright cherry red, at which it is maintained for from 3 to 7 days. The boxes are then removed and allowed to cool slowly; the castings are usually finished by "rumbling." The mill scale and the spent oxide from the boxes are frequently treated with a weak solution of sal-ammoniac, to promote the combination with them of oxygen from the atmosphere, so as to serve again.

description: The Walloon process for the production of wrought iron from cast iron was introduced into Sweden in the first quarter of the 17th century by Louis de Geer from Flanders, where it was probably developed. The process has been supplanted by the more economical Lancashire hearth process (see No. 24), except at one or two places, like Dannemora, where iron of the very highest quality for the production of cast steel is made. The furnace is constructed of cast-iron plates, lined with firebrick, resting on a foundation provided with suitable air channels to keep it cool. The bottom plate is protected by a layer of hammer slag. Cold blast from an overhead pipe, controlled by a butterfly valve, is supplied to a copper tuyère (not water-cooled) at one side; the fore plate or work table is in front. The pigs, which are white or mottled, are pushed in from the back, the hearth is filled with charcoal, and the blast turned on so that they melt in front of the tuyère. When sufficient iron has melted off the ends of the pigs, they are withdrawn a short distance. In their passage through the blast the drops of iron are partially oxidised. The iron gathered in the hearth is now in contact with the slag, the reaction causing further removal of carbon. Meanwhile, the iron is brought up with a bar, portion by portion, into the blast, when a further oxidisation and refining take place. The iron, now in the form of pasty lumps, is brought into the hottest part of the hearth and the lumps worked into balls. These are removed from the furnace and consolidated into a bloom under a tilt hammer. The first reheating of this for drawing into bars is carried out in the same hearth during the first period of the subsequent operation. The time between heats is 60 mins. The charge consists of about 200 lb. of pig; an equal quantity of charcoal is consumed in the operation. The weight of bloom produced is about 80 per cent. of that of the pig iron charged. The furnaces are usually arranged in a line opposite to a row of tilt hammers worked by water-power; a suitable building covers them.

The process has been supplanted by the more economical Lancashire hearth process (see No. 24), except at one or two places, like Dannemora, where iron of the very highest quality for the production of cast steel is made.

description: (Scale 1:10.) (Walloon Process.) This type of furnace was considerably used for the conversion of cast into wrought iron, by fusing it in an oxidising flame and then working in a slag bath of iron oxide contained on the hearth. The hearth, built up with iron plates, has the floor plate water-cooled and is lined with charcoal. The fuel, usually charcoal, is placed on the hearth, and the combustion forced by a blast from a tuyère inclining downwards. The cast iron is slowly melted off the end of a long pig or slab overhanging the hearth and fed in from the left-hand side. The partially purified iron is subsequently almost completely decarbonised by being worked in the molten bath of iron oxide, and, when in the pasty condition, is collected into a ball and forged into bars. Through a hole in the front of the hearth any excess of slag is discharged. The hearth is surmounted by a brickwork chimney provided with several baffle plates.

description: The “direct” process here illustrated is that of the late Sir C. W. Siemens, in which a mixture of iron ore and fine coal is heated in a chamber containing a reducing atmosphere. This chamber, shown on the right-hand side of the model, consists of a lined wrought-iron cylinder capable of being slowly revolved, and known as the “rotator.” It is charged at the front end, and when this is done a reducing flame is directed into its interior from two pairs of firebrick regenerator chambers filled with chequer work, one pair of which is brought to a red heat before starting work. The gases and coal dust reduce the iron ore to the metallic state, whilst the continual rolling, causing the rotation of the chamber, collects the grains of iron into a bloom; the slag is tapped out at a special form a fluid slag. The rotator being stopped, the slag, which is of very aperture and carried to the slag pit. The bloom, which is of very pure iron, is finally withdrawn through the central aperture and carried to the gas-fired reverberatory furnace seen on the extreme left. This furnace shows the four regenerator chambers below, as well as the reversing valves, all of which are similar to those required by the rotator, although grouped differently. Blooms from the rotator may be left on this bed, to drain off the large amount of slag that they contain, before transferring them to the melting furnace. In the centre of the model is a furnace with a fixed bed formed into one shallow and two deep cavities. Blooms from the rotator may be kept hot before chamber. At the back of the model is Siemens’s cascade furnace for melting a bath of oxide of iron in a cavity on the upper level of the furnace bed; the oxide is afterwards allowed to flow over heated charcoal lying in the lower bed, and is thus reduced. The blooms so obtained could be used in the ordinary open-hearth furnaces.

description: This represents a complete plant as designed by Sir Henry Bessemer for the conversion of cast iron into steel by the process patented and introduced by him in 1856. The change is effected by blowing air through the molten cast iron, thus burning out the carbon as well as the silicon, and so converting the mass into steel. The mechanical difficulties in such an operation were formidable, but the inventor solved them by a series of inventions that have remained substantially unaltered. The model shows two 3-ton converters (AA), placed on opposite sides of the casting pit, in the centre of which is a hydraulic crane (C), carrying the casting ladle. This crane can be swung round so that the ladle can receive its charge from either converter, and is provided with a bottom tapping hole, by which the contents can be run into ingots in a series of tapered iron moulds arranged circularly. Just outside the pit are two hydraulic cranes (DD) for stripping the moulds and lifting the ingots. Opposite the pit are the valves (B), viz., the air valves for controlling the blowing, and the hydraulic valves for controlling the raising and lowering of the converters and the lifting of the ladle crane. On the platform of the ladle crane itself are the handles for turning the gear, for swinging the ladle round to carry the charge of steel from the converters to the ingot moulds, and also the tipping gear for emptying the residue and slag from the ladle ; there is also a locking gear to hold the ladle upright. A pair of vertical engines work two 3-throw sets of hydraulic pumps (E), and a pair of horizontal high-pressure blowing engines (FF) supply the air, which is blown into the metal at a pressure of from 15 to 25 lb. per sq. in., through the tuyères in the bottom of the converters (see No. 37).

Through the small holes in the upper end of the tuyère the blast is admitted, and as these holes enlarge as the tuyères burn away a simple means of fixing is employed, so that any damaged tuyère can be quickly replaced.

description: This shows a Bessemer plant, in which the amount of labour and fuel required has been reduced by later improvements. The molten cast iron is brought in a ladle running on rails to a lift beneath the converter platform. This lift raises the truck with the ladle to the higher level, when the contents are poured into the large ladle leading into the converter. After blowing, the steel is poured into a ladle carried by a circular crane, from which it is teemed into the casting ladle; carried by the central crane of the casting pit. The steel is then run into the ingot moulds in the usual manner, and as soon as sufficiently set the moulds are stripped off by one of the small hydraulic cranes and the hot ingots transferred by a similar crane to a soaking pit. These pits, which were patented in 1882 by Mr. J. Gjers, were first introduced at the Darlington Steel and Iron Works. By their adoption the time and fuel required in re-heating the ingots before rolling, together with the consequent wasting of the metal, are saved. A freshly cast ingot is much hotter in the interior than at the surface, and this unequal distribution of temperature prevented its being worked until it had cooled and been re-heated; but by placing the ingot for some time in a closed firebrick chamber the heat becomes uniformly distributed, so that the ingot, when withdrawn from this soaking pit, is in a fit state for rolling down into billets in the cogging mill shown. In modern practice soaking pits are arranged for gas-firing, so as to obviate the necessity of having to make re-heating furnaces for the cold in ingots. A separate sectional model of the soaking pits, to a scale of 1 : 6, is exhibited beneath the model of the general arrangement.

collection: SECTIONAL MODEL OF BASIC STEEL FURNACE
object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF BASIC STEEL FURNACE
description:
This represents a 25-ton open-hearth regenerative steel-melting furnace, forming one of a series designed by Mr. Bernard Dawson and erected at the Earl of Dudley’s Steel Works at Round Oak, Staffordshire. The steel is made from a charge of pig iron, oxide of iron, steel scrap, and lime, which is melted on the hearth of a reverberatory furnace whose bed is covered with a basic lining formed of dolomite or magnesite. The oxygen in the charge consumes the excess carbon in the cast iron, while the phosphorus is removed by the flux formed from the basic lining; an addition of ferro-manganese is, however, made after tapping to ensure the improved qualities that the presence of manganese promotes.
The open hearth of the furnace consists of a shallow rectangular pan of cast-iron plates supported on girders, which permit of the free circulation of air below it to keep it cool, and protected above by a covering of firebrick and the thick lining of basic material which forms the bed of the hearth; the roof over the hearth is formed by a silica brick arch, and the side walls are also of silica brick, but are externally protected by a wrought-iron casing, strengthened by vertical rods or buckstaves, held together by long transverse tie-rods.
The furnace is entirely heated by the combustion of producer gas, which, together with the necessary air, is introduced through ports at one end of the hearth, after passing over which the gases escape by similar ports and down through the large regenerator chambers beneath the furnace, and thence to a flue leading to a stack. The producer gas is supplied through a gas flue, from which it passes under a mushroom valve, regulated by a hand wheel on the charging platform, and past a butterfly reversing valve to a flue communicating with the bottom of the outer and smaller of the pair of regenerator chambers at the end of the furnace. It then ascends through the interstices between the open brick-work with which the chamber is packed, and thence through a vertical flue and central port at the end of the hearth. The air for the combustion of this gas enters another flue by a similar mushroom valve, worked from the charging platform, and, passing a butterfly reversing valve, reaches a flue leading to the bottom of the inner and larger of this pair of regenerators, through the brickwork packing of which it passes to the two upper ports at this end of the hearth. The combustible mixture thus arriving at this end of the hearth burns forming a continuous sheet of flame, which passes along the hearth and through the three corresponding ports at the opposite end and down through the open brickwork into a similar pair of regenerators beneath that end of the furnace, and then through the horizontal flues to the butterfly reversing valves, by which the considerably cooled gases are passed to a flue, fitted with a sliding damper, controlled from the platform, and communicating with the stack, which gives the draught and also carries away the products of combustion.
When the furnace has been working in this way for about half an hour, the direction of the gases is reversed, so that the producer gas and the air for its combustion are passed through the heated brickwork of the other pair of regenerators, and are thus raised to a high temperature before entering into combustion over the hearth, the rejected heat at the other end of the hearth being similarly absorbed by the other pair of regenerators. This reversal of the course of the gases is effected by the two butterfly valves arranged beneath the gas and air valves and controlled by levers from the charging platform.
After the heating has been maintained for about 10 hrs. and the charge is ready for tapping, the tap-hole is pierced, so that the metal flows into a hinged shoot, which conveys it into a casting ladle, mounted on a carriage running on rails on the sides of the casting pit in which the ingot moulds are arranged. The ferro-manganese and any nickel that may be required are added in a heated, but solid, condition to the metal while it is flowing into this casting ladle. The metal is delivered into the moulds through a hole in the bottom of the ladle, fitted with a plug, which can be lifted by an external lever. When the whole of the metal has been "teemed" the ladle is turned over by means of worm gear and the slag poured into a cast-iron slag pot, while the slag remaining in the hearth of the furnace is run off by the hinged shoot into another slag pot.

description: This furnace is an example of a tilting furnace, built on rockers, so that the hearth section of the furnace can be tilted to enable the charge of finished steel to be poured direct into the ladle. The furnace is mounted on rockers, and can be tilted to any required angle for pouring by a vertical hydraulic ram on the tapping side. When the basic process is in operation, the furnace offers the advantage of enabling a highly phosphoric or siliceous slag to be poured off during the operation. The pouring hole, being above the level of the metal, is not rammed up in the usual manner, but is closed loosely with sand, so that hard taps are avoided, and the metal can be poured directly it is ready.

description: This represents a machine for charging open-hearth furnaces; it was patented in this country in 1890 and 1896 by Messrs. S. T. & C. H. Wellman, and has since been extended in its application. It is of the “high ground” type, i.e., it is arranged above the ordinary charging level, but low ground and overhead types are also made. The charge of pig iron and scrap is loaded in special charging boxes, three at a time, on bogies, which are pushed along rails on the charging platform immediately in front of the furnaces. The machine consists of a built-up steel carriage capable of travelling on rails parallel with those for the bogies. The carriage supports overhead rails at right angles to these, and along them moves a truck whence is suspended on trunnions a charging arm, which is capable of motion through a vertical arc by cranks and connecting rods at the rear, where the operator’s platform is situated. To prevent running back, this motion is fitted with a magnetic brake of the multiple disc type. The end of the arm is squared to enter a slot in the end of the charging box, where it is locked by a rod passing up the centre of the arm. The arm is tilted and the whole machine travels along till it is opposite the door of the furnace to be charged (as shown). The arm is then traversed by the truck until the box is over the desired part of the bed. The forward part of the arm is turned by spur gearing till the box is emptied, and the latter is withdrawn and replaced on the bogie. The cycle of operations takes ½ to 1 min. Separate series-wound electric motors, with reduction spur gearing, are provided for (i) travelling the machine, (ii) traversing, (iii) tilting it, (iv) turning the arm; these, with the locking rod lever, are under the control of one man. The controllers are of the Dinkey type. The current is collected by sliding contacts from overhead conductors. The machine represented is capable of charging a 50-ton furnace in 22 mins., a saving in time as compared with hand labour of about 15 per cent., while operating costs are also reduced.

description: MODEL OF CONTINUOUS OPEN-HEARTH FURNACE. (Scale 1:24.) Lent by the Talbot Continuous Steel Process, Ltd. This modification of the open-hearth steel process for increasing the rapidity of production was introduced in 1889 by Mr. B. Talbot, at Pencoyd, U.S.A. The differences between this process and the ordinary one are: the use of fluid pig iron to save time and to avoid lowering the temperature; the oxidation of the metalloids entirely by oxide of iron instead of by the latter and air conjointly, thereby increasing the yield by about 5 per cent.; the maintenance of a large reserve of heat by tapping out a portion only of the charge at one time. A basic lining and a tilting hearth of the Wellman type are found to be most suitable for the process. The hearth portion is built up of steel framing enclosing the brickwork; there are three rockers which each rest on two rollers. The whole is fixed to the frame and three rockers which each rest on two rollers. The whole is mounted on trunnions, the tilting is effected by two hydraulic cylinders on the tapping side, mounted on trunnions, the rams being attached to the top front edge; the tapping platforms are also hung by rods from this edge and move with it. To allow for this tilting, the frames enclosing the brickwork of the blocks, through which come the air and gas ports, have a slight motion vertically and horizontally by means of hydraulic cylinders. The furnace has five charging doors and a Wellman charging machine is provided for the solid material. The overhead crane on this side lifts the ladle of fluid metal brought from the mixer or direct from the blast furnace or cupola; the overhead crane on the tapping side takes the ladle of steel to the required place over the track on which are the bogies supporting the ingot moulds. During Sunday the furnace is charged with molten iron and steel, and this charge is worked down in the same way as in the fixed furnace. When ready, the furnace is tilted and one-fourth to one-third of the charge is tapped, the addition of ferro-manganese being made as usual, but the slag is not run off. The necessary lime and iron ore are added and with the slag already present form a highly oxidising body. A quantity of molten iron, equal to that of the steel just tapped, is poured into the bath and an immediate reaction occurs with evolution on the surface of CO, which burns with an intense flame; during this period, and also during tapping, the gas supply is shut off. After this characteristic “boiling” has gone on for about 15 min. part of the slag, now nearly deprived of iron oxides, is tapped off and the bath worked down with the help of fresh lime and ore. A like quantity of steel is tapped and the tap-hole and bottom repaired. This cycle is repeated during the rest of the week, the bath being emptied only on Saturday; in some works a charge is left in over the week-end. The furnace shown is of 200 tons capacity; about 30 charges are obtained in the week.

description: This forms part of a complete model illustrating the manufacture of steel in Sheffield in 1850 (see Nos. 46–8). The cementation process, for converting wrought iron into steel, consists in maintaining wrought iron for several days at a red heat while embedded in charcoal and protected from the air, whereby the iron gradually absorbs carbon, which combines with it and converts it into steel. The method is a development of the case-hardening process, and is very old, but Réaumur, in a work published in 1722, appears to have been the first to examine it experimentally; he also describes the furnaces then in use, which were very similar to those employed at Sheffield and elsewhere. The wrought iron to be treated, usually in the form of 3 in. by 0.75 in. high-quality flat bars, is packed in open rectangular chests or “pots,” built of sandstone or firebrick, which are placed on either side of a long coal-fired grate, the products of combustion being carried through a series of flues along the bottom, sides, and ends of the chest. These flues open into an enclosing arched firebrick chamber, provided with doorways at the ends, and three short chimneys or eyes on each side just at the springing of the arch, so as to create a distributed draught. The whole is sheltered under a hollow cone of brickwork, about 50 ft. high, which retains much of the heat, and delivers the waste gases at a sufficient elevation, while preventing the formation of a strong draught. These cementation plants are usually built in groups, as shown, with each chest measuring from 10 to 15 ft. in length by 2.5 to 3 ft. square, and holding 8 to 12 tons of wrought iron. The bars are packed between layers of wood charcoal, and when the chest is full the top is plastered over with clay or “wheel-swarf,” a mixture of silica and oxide of iron from the grinderies, which, when heated frits and forms an airtight lid. The entrances of the chamber are walled up and the fire lighted, so that in two or three days the chests are at a glowing red heat, i.e., a temperature of 1,170° C., which is maintained for five or six days. The fire is then drawn and the furnace allowed to cool during two or three more days, in which time, however, the process is still proceeding and completing itself. At intervals during the process, bars left protruding from the side openings, in order to judge, from their fracture, of the extent of the conversion, which is varied according to the purpose for which the steel is to be used. The coal consumed is about equal in weight to that of the steel produced, and the capacity of each furnace is about 26 tons per week. The surfaces of the bars after treatment are covered with blisters of various sizes, so that this material is known as “blister steel.” In this form it is very rarely used, but is subsequently forged into some of the various grades of shear steel, or else melted in crucibles.

collection: SECTIONAL MODEL OF STEEL CASTING HOUSE
object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF STEEL CASTING HOUSE
description: This forms part of a complete model illustrating the manufacture of cementation steel in Sheffield in 1850 (see Nos. 45, 47, 48). Neither blister nor shear steel is homogeneous, so that to obtain the uniform material necessary for making the finest cutlery, etc., fusion becomes necessary. This requires a very high temperature, as well as considerable skill in melting, but the process was introduced and brought to a practical success by Benjamin Huntsman in 1740, who, after he had prepared suitable crucibles and furnaces for the exceptional requirements, established works in 1770 at Attercliffe, where the firm still exists and some of the original furnaces remain. The furnace is simply a rectangular chamber built of firebrick and ganister, and is usually capable of holding two crucibles. The bottom of the furnace is formed by a grate of firebars, while a side flue at the top communicates with a chimney stack; it is usual to arrange a series of furnaces or melting holes in a row, each with its own stack formed in a wall common to the series, as shown in the model. The common furnace top is slightly above the level of the casting floor, and each “hole” is provided with a removable firebrick cover, so that the charge and fuel may be introduced through the top, while the whole of the interior is accessible for cleaning from an arched cellar below. The crucibles and fires are also reduced in this way. The crucibles are usually made from a mixture of Stourbridge and Stannington clays, with a small quantity of ground pots and coke-dust; they weigh from 15 to 25 lb. upwards, and hold from 30 to 50 lb. of steel. The new crucibles are dried gradually on shelves above the furnaces for a week, and are annealed at a red heat before use in an open fire arranged in one corner of the melting house. The crucibles are withdrawn from the holes by hand labour, and their contents poured into the ingot moulds shown.

object_name: MODEL OF TILT HAMMERS WITH HEATING FURNACES
description: This and the succeeding model form part of a complete model illustrating the manufacture of tool steel in Sheffield in 1850 (see Nos. 45-6). By piling, welding, and hammering, blister steel is rendered more homogeneous and improved in quality, the product being known as “shear steel” from its having been originally used for making shears for woollen cloth. The form of tilt hammer represented has a steel-faced head, weighing from 120 to 500 lb., wedged on to a wooden shaft, which is hooped with iron and provided with a cast-iron trunnion hoop by which it is supported on brasses, adjustable in vertical standards by folding wedges. The tail of the hammer shaft is depressed periodically by a number of tappets projecting from a wheel on a shaft rotated by water or steam power, so that from 150 to 350 drop blows are made per minute, while the workman advances and turns the heated bar upon the anvil as the work proceeds. To diminish vibration, the anvil usually rests on a wooden block, hooped with iron and bedded in the heavy masonry foundation. The furnace used for heating the bars is of a construction which forms a link between the open forge and the reverberatory furnace, and is known as a hollow fire. It is simply an enclosed chamber, partially filled with coke and supplied with a forced blast, so that when a bar to be heated is inserted in the space above the fire the fuel does not come into actual contact with it. The products of combustion escape through various openings and are carried off by a hood above, which in the model is shown covering two furnaces. (N.B.—These furnaces are, in the model, shown nearer the hammers than they would be in practice.)

object_name: MODEL OF ROLLING MILLS WITH HEATING FURNACES
description:
(Scale 1:8.) Presented by Messrs. Naylor, Vickers & Co. Squeezing between rolls is the most rapid method of reducing a slab of iron or steel to the form of plate or sheet metal, and nearly all other materials possessing the necessary qualifications for standing the treatment are also reduced in this way. In 1784 Henry Cort, by the introduction of grooved and collared rolls, vastly increased the value of the rolling mill, as he thus enabled it to prepare round and flat bars, together with the other numerous sections since employed as rails and girders. In bringing a mass of metal from a large to a smaller section, working under a hammer appears to be most beneficial, but the greater rapidity and economy of the rolling process renders its use almost universal, except for the preliminary forging of the highest qualities of cast steel. The rolls used in the preliminary forging of heavy masses of iron and steel have rolls of from 4 ft. diam. downwards; but the mill here represented is of a lighter type, as it is only intended for treating crucible cast-steel ingots.
The engine (not shown) is placed between the sheet mill and the bar mill, and the lower line of rolls in each mill is directly driven, while the top roll is driven from it by pinions arranged in stands or housings at each side of the engine. The distance between the rolls is adjusted by screws through the top ends or housings, which limit the amount to which the top roll may rise when the bar or plate is passing beneath it; to allow for this vertical play, the ends of the rolls are made square and are connected by a short square shaft, which is coupled to the adjacent ends by loosely-fitting cast-iron muffs or boxes, which, while giving the requisite freedom, also protect the rolls in case of accident, since these inexpensive boxes will break before a roll is injured.
The sheet mill has a single stand of rolls, 16 in. diam., while the bar mill has four stands of rolls of 9 in. diam., for preparing round, square, and flat sections; in front of these rolls is a table for supporting the end of a bar before passing it into the rolls, and for some of the sections a directing guide is clamped to the table for ensuring the entry of the rod into the intended groove. With only two rolls in a housing, it is usual, after a bar has passed over the top and then pass it in the original direction through the next set of grooves or rolls. In dealing with large sections it is more usual to reverse the engine so that the bar or plate is given its next passage while entering from the opposite side; the same result is also obtained by having three rolls, the first pass being through the lower pair and the return through the upper pair, without reversing the engine.
Near these rolls is shown a shearing machine, also driven from the engine, used for cutting bars into lengths for piling and for cropping the finished rods.
As the steel can only be successfully and economically rolled at a red heat, it is necessary to have furnaces near the mill for heating the material, or for re-heating it should it cool too much during the rolling process; these furnaces are here arranged in pairs with a common stack, one pair being for heating piles of bars, while the other is for sheets.
(N.B.—The re-heating furnaces are shown nearer the rolling mill than they would be in practice.)

object_name: MODEL OF REGENERATIVE FURNACE FOR CRUCIBLE STEEL
description: MODEL OF REGENERATIVE FURNACE FOR CRUCIBLE STEEL. (Scale 1 : 12.) Made from drawings prepared in the Museum. This shows the modification made in the furnaces used for melting steel in crucibles by the application, for the purpose of reducing the fuel consumption, of the Siemens regenerative principle, which appears to have first been adapted to this work in 1862. Several positions for the regenerators have been tried, e.g., they have been built at the ends of the melting chamber, and at right angles to one side, but the most usual arrangement is as here shown, with the regenerators alongside and below the general level. The hearth, or melting chamber, is divided by cross walls into from two to ten holes, each accommodating six crucibles. Each melting hole, or laboratory, is so short, except in the arrangement where the regenerators are at the two ends, that it is necessary to mix the air and gas intimately before they enter this region; contrary to the usual practice with open-hearth furnaces, nearest the melting chamber, and the stream of gas for this purpose the gas regenerator is placed, brought up through three small ports into the corresponding horizontal streams of air; in addition, the ports on opposite sides are out of line, so as to ensure cross currents. The resulting flame is bent downward by a deflecting arch, so as to be concentrated upon the crucibles, which stand on a bed of coke-dust supported on ribbed cast-iron plates, resting on side walls and cooled by an air space left below; these bottom plates have holes in them which are closed by old lids, etc., but allow access to each melting hole for cleaning out the clinker at the end of a week's run, or should a crucible break. The top of each melting hole is closed by a cover, made in three pieces, which are handled by a lever supported on the axle of a two-wheeled bogie, or by a chain from wheels on an overhead rail. The crucibles are lifted, after the gas and air have been shut off, by the "puller out," who uses tongs which partially embrace them, and the metal is poured by a "teemer," who uses a pair of tongs which holds the crucible at right angles to those for lifting; the other pair of tongs is for removing the cover of the crucible. The gas from the producers is brought to the regenerators, and so to the furnace, through a culvert, and the waste gases from the regenerators pass in a similar way to a chimney (not shown). The admission of gas and air is regulated by mushroom valves, adjustable by hand wheels at the floor level, and the currents of air and gas are reversed at intervals by ordinary flap valves moved by levers. The consumption of fuel over extended periods has been found to be about 1 lb. of slack coal to the pound of ingot poured, and, owing to the ready control of the temperature, the labour of handling the crucibles is reduced, so that the charges melted are from 60 to 80 lb., and even heavier where plumbago crucibles are used. On the other hand, the first cost of the furnace is greater than that of the earlier type.

description: These illustrate stages in the manufacture of high-temper cast steel. The series commences with Swedish wrought iron, which is changed into blister steel by treatment in the cementation furnace. These blister bars are broken up and melted in crucibles. The crucible steel is cast into ingots, which are broken up into specimens at the sides, which are afterwards drawn out by tilt hammers to small sections, producing the various tempers of steel shown, in which the amount of carbon varies from 0.75 to 1.5 per cent., but for the higher qualities several re-meltings are usually performed. Fractures of ingots of cast steel, containing tungsten and chromium, are also shown.
interpretation: These illustrate stages in the manufacture of high-temper cast steel.

description: MODEL OF TILTING CRUCIBLE FURNACE. (Scale 1: 4.) Lent by the Morgan Crucible Co., Ltd. In modern practice, instead of a small crucible heated by means of coke in a pit fire, whence it must be lifted by hand, thereby exposing the workman to the heat and fumes from the fuel, a large crucible, heated in a self-contained regenerative tilting furnace, is made use of. The construction shown was patented in 1903 by Mr. C. W. Spiers and the Morgan Crucible Co. The furnace proper has a double steel shell, the outside one being octagonal and the inside one circular in section. The lining is of specially shaped firebricks, in which are radial ports or ducts. The salamander crucible is supported on a stand, and is held in a central position by means of grip bricks, which also prevent it from shifting during tilting. The grate bars are arranged in three sections, so that the fuel or clinker can be withdrawn at the end of a run by the removal of the two side sections, leaving the central section, with the crucible, undisturbed. Above the furnace body is the "pre-heater" section, consisting of a steel shell with a flue outlet branch and a sliding top cover, all of which are lined with firebrick. The pre-heater, besides acting as a combustion chamber, enables a larger bulk of metal to be charged than the crucible will hold at the outset. This metal is accommodated in an extension cylinder fitted above the crucible. The pre-heater, while enabling convenience also when adding metal to the charge, and incidentally protects the metal from the waste gases, which contain sulphurous fumes. The cylinder is a convenient flue pipe so that it can be lifted by means of a cam and swung off sideways when the furnace body is to be tilted. The downtake flue pipe acts as a regenerator because it consists of a cast-iron pipe, spirally gilled externally, through which the waste gases pass to the chimney, while through the annular spiral flue, but in the reverse direction, the incoming air from an electrically driven or other blower passes to the ashpit; thence a portion goes through the grate, while the remainder passes through the space between the two shells of the furnace body to the ports in the lining. An intensely hot melting zone, the full depth of the crucible, results from this method of heat regeneration and air supply, while economy in fuel and materials and a large output is attained. The furnace body is tilted on trunnions close to the top edge by means of links, connected with counter-balanced levers, keyed to a quadrant actuated by worm and bevel gear from a hand wheel. The pouring point is practically constant and the pour can be accurately adjusted. The model represents a stationary coke-fired furnace (Type A), taking a 400 lb. crucible. The blast pressure is usually from 3 to 4 in. water gauge, but depends on the metal being melted. Other types, which have portable bodies to be used like foundry ladles, or are arranged for oil or gas firing, are made.

description: This collection consists of 170 specimens of metals, chiefly ferrous, illustrative of their manufacture in India. In ancient times iron was always extracted directly from its ores as malleable iron, and to this day the same primitive method is practised in many parts of India, Africa, and Borneo. The ores, generally magnetic oxide or rich hæmatites, are smelted in a furnace which, in its rudest form, is a miniature clay shaft, the shaft being often not more than 3 ft. high. The fuel used is charcoal and the blast is obtained by means of bellows made from a goat skin. The lumps of iron are hammered out into a solid mass, which is then extended into bar form by re-heating and hammering. Steel is also produced in some districts by direct smelting from iron ores. The furnaces used for this purpose are generally larger, and a mass of malleable iron and steel is obtained from which the steely parts are carefully selected and prepared for use by heating in a charcoal fire at a low-red heat. "Wootz steel" was prepared by the Hindoos by melting pieces of wrought iron, together with pieces of wood (the stem of the cassia auriculata), and one or two large green leaves of a species of convolvulus, in small unbaked clay crucibles placed in a charcoal fire in a shallow pit. From 14 to 24 crucibles were heated in the pit at once, the fire being urged by bellows. Wootz steel is a high carbon steel containing about 1.5 per cent. of carbon. It can only be forged at a low red heat, and was used for making swords and knives.
