object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF HÉROULT ELECTRIC FURNACE
description: Made from information supplied by Messrs. Campbell & Gifford, Ltd. This is a typical example of the class of electric furnaces in which the heat is produced mainly by an arc, and to a much smaller extent by the resistance offered by the whole or a portion of the charge to a powerful electric current. The furnace is used for melting and refining Bessemer or open-hearth scrap, and for the manufacture of alloy steels. The furnace is essentially an open-hearth tilting furnace, resembling in many ways the Wellman furnace. It is lined with basic material. Two or three electrodes pass through the roof, water-cooling chambers being placed at the piercing points, in order to keep the external portions of the electrodes and the brickwork of the roof at permissible temperatures. The electrodes may be raised or lowered by electric motor-driven mechanism, controlled by hand or automatically. In the latter case, variations in the voltage or current in the furnace, within defined limits, actuate the mechanism which controls the motor. At the ends of the furnace, where the gas ports are found in an ordinary Wellman furnace, are charging doors, and there is a movable door over the pouring spout. In starting the furnace for melting and refining, some lime and iron ore are placed upon the furnace bottom, followed by wrought-iron and steel scrap. The electrodes are lowered to establish an electric circuit (the charge being in actual contact with them), the iron melting numerous small arcs and high-resistance contacts are formed, causing violent fluctuations of current until all the metal is molten. The electrodes are then raised just clear of the bath, so that the air-gaps are bridged by arcs. The current thus passes from one electrode through the air-gap to the slag, through the slag to the metal, and back through the same layer of slag to the other electrode. If the electrodes are lowered to or just below the surface of the slag, the furnace becomes a pure resistance furnace. When the bath is completely molten, and violent fluctuations of current have ceased, a 3-ton furnace will require an alternating current of about 4,000 amps. at 110 volts for normal working. These furnaces are usually fed from transformers, two of which are shown near the furnace in this model.

description: This sectional example represents a small induction furnace in which a high-frequency current, applied to a primary circuit, induces a current in a mass of metal contained in a crucible, the metal itself constituting the secondary circuit. The heat generated by the passage of the secondary current melts the metal. The furnace consists of a cylindrical vessel or crucible, for holding the metal, the crucible being lined on the outside with zirconia and mica. This outside lining serves as a heat insulator for keeping the heat within the crucible, and as an electrical insulator to the copper coil, which is wound around it and which carries the primary current. The copper coil is a flattened tube through which a flow of water can be maintained, the high frequency current being applied to the terminals of this coil, or solenoid. The furnace is provided with long handles, which enable it to be tilted for pouring, and during melting a tight-fitting cover provides effective heat insulation. The current is supplied to the copper coil through a “converter set,” consisting essentially of an oil-cooled transformer with high internal reactance; by this means, currents of commercial frequency are changed into the high-frequency and high-voltage current required.

description: This is copied from the furnace formerly largely used in South Wales for calcining copper regulus. The regulus, received in a granulated condition, was first dried in the large cast-iron pan resting upon the roof of the furnace. It was then delivered through two apertures on to the flat bed, and there spread out by the aid of rabbles. When sufficiently calcined, the material was raked out through apertures, seen in the furnace bed just in front of the working doors. Each door was provided with an iron roller on which to rest the heavy iron rabbles, and also with a short chimney to carry any escaping fumes away from the workmen. There was a door just under the flue leading to the chimney stack by which an inspection of the interior could be made without admitting air to the charge.
interpretation: This sectional model represents a reverberatory furnace formerly largely used in South Wales for calcining copper regulus. The process involved drying granulated regulus in a cast-iron pan, spreading it on a flat bed with rabbles, and raking it out after calcination. Doors with iron rollers for rabbles and short chimneys for fumes were incorporated. An inspection door allowed for internal checks without admitting air.

description: This model shows the common type of smelting furnace still generally used for the smelting of copper ores. Its general construction is somewhat similar to No. 58, but, as the temperature required is much higher, several differences in detail are necessary. The ore is delivered from a hopper, mounted upon a pair of rails, immediately above the roof, but this mode of charging has ceased to be generally adopted. The firegrate is much larger than that of the previous example, and is provided with an arched roof, the bed of the furnace is made of refractory sand, is slightly hollow, and is formed upon the top of arches that open into the ash-pit, so that air can circulate beneath the bed and cool the foundation. A tap-hole is provided to the bed so as to permit of the withdrawal of melted regulus through the side of the furnace on the opposite side to the charging door. The roof of the furnace is formed of a flat arch continuous with that over the firegrate, and is provided at the end furthest from the fire with a flue leading to the stack. Immediately under this flue a second working door will be seen through which the slag can be drawn from the surface of the bath of molten material. Moulds are provided at this door to catch the slag, whilst other moulds beneath the tap-hole receive the melted regulus.

description: This represents a type of furnace introduced at Freiberg in 1865 by Bergrat Pilz, and since extensively used in Europe and America for smelting copper and lead ores. Its leading feature is the presence of a water-cooled belt round the hottest zone, which cools the walls of the furnace, and thus diminishes the wear where it would otherwise be most rapid. The heat carried away by the water is a direct loss, but is, however, much more than compensated for by the longer life and reduced cost of maintenance of the furnace thereby attained; by some it is considered, moreover, that the lowered temperature of the hearth prevents the reduction of iron in certain ores in which it occurs as an impurity. The shaft of the furnace is of brick in an iron shell, and is carried on metal columns, so that it is not disturbed when repairs are being effected in the hearth. The hearth is of brick, and upon it rests the water belt, which is built up of eight segmental boxes, each pierced by a tuyère and supplied with circulating water. In the early Pilz furnaces the tuyères were arranged between the segments of the belt. Blast is supplied at a pressure of about 0.7 lb. per sq. in. from an octagonal main; the charge is fed through a closed cylindrical trunk at the top, and the waste gases escape through a side flue. The molten metal, regulus, and slag collect in the hearth, and at intervals the regulus and slag are tapped into slag pots, while at longer intervals the molten metal is run out through two tap-holes at the bottom of the hearth.

description: This sectional model represents a modern blast furnace, known as the “Cananea” or “Shelby” pattern, for the pyritic smelting of copper ores. Theoretically, pyritic smelting is the process of reducing sulphide ores without the aid of carbonaceous fuel, heat being furnished by the combustion of the sulphur in the ore. In practice, however, in the case of low-grade ores, recourse must be had to coke fuel sometimes in conjunction with a moderately hot blast. This is known as “compromise pyritic smelting.” The product is a matte or regulus. The furnace is rectangular, with water-jacketed boshes extending from the bottom plates to the charging floor level. These bottom plates are of cast iron, heavily ribbed and supported from the floor by jack screws, which permit of their being lowered when necessary independently of the rest of the furnace. All brickwork is dispensed with below the charging-floor level, except that in the crucible bottom. This is a lining of firebricks, covered with a layer, 3 in. to 4 in. thick of “brasque,” a mixture of ground fireclay and coke tamped into a crucible form. The water-jackets are in six sections, 35 in. wide, and the end ones 2 ft. wide, each with its independent water circulation; they are made of m.s. plates, flanged outwards so that no seam is exposed to the fire. The side jacket inner plates are 0.375 in. thick and the outer plates 0.3125 in. thick. The side jackets are eleven air doors, one for each jacket inner plates, and four at each end in the outer plates. Above this, again, is the lattice girder superstructure carrying the hood, 0.3125 in. thick, and other shaft extensions. The matte is discharged continuously through the water-cooled cast-iron or copper tymp or spout into an oval-shaped settler or forehearth, 23.5 ft. by 15 ft. lined with fire and chrome-brick. The outer shell is made of m.s. plates, 0.3125 in. thick, and is water-cooled by being sprayed from a perforated pipe suspended round the top. The water is run off by a gutter at the base of the hearth. The matte is tapped out of this into a ladle for transporting it to the Bessemer converter. The slag spout is seen on the right of the furnace. Inv. 1919-497, S.M. 1217-8.

description: The specimens shown illustrate the method by which Cowper-Coles deposited copper electrolytically in the form of tubes, sheet, or wire on a revolving cathode. To determine the critical speed at which good deposition will take place, a cone, having the form of a cone, is rotated in the electrolyte; the part of the cone on which smooth deposition takes place shows the critical circumferential speed which it is necessary to maintain on the mandrel which is to act as the cathode. Smooth and thick deposits of copper, which are free from lamination and have good tensile strength, can be obtained by this method of deposition. For the production of wire, a mandrel, on which a spiral groove has been cut, is used. This groove, which is not deeply cut, but must have an angular section, gives to the deposited copper a line of cleavage, and enables the deposit to be unwound at an angle from the mandrel in the form of wire.

collection: SPECIMENS ILLUSTRATING THE ELECTROLYTIC PROCESS FOR THE MANUFACTURE OF PARABOLIC REFLECTORS
description: Parabolic reflectors are used for searchlights and similar purposes, and the properties which are chiefly sought in them are true reflection and resistance to tarnishing by heat, damp, and sea water. By the deposition process represented, a parabolic mirror is formed by depositing copper electrolytically upon the silvered surface of a convex glass mould; the mould being slowly rotated in the copper sulphate electrolyte. The convex side of the glass mould is accurately ground and very highly polished, and the surface of the copper reflector, when detached from the mould, is bright and a perfect replica of it. The deposited reflector is easily detached from the glass mould by placing in lukewarm water and raising the temperature to 120° F. The uneven expansion of the glass and copper detaches the reflector from the mould. The reflector is given a protective coating of some metal, such as palladium. A bright coating of this metal is easily and rapidly deposited on the reflector by placing it in a bath containing a palladium salt as an electrolyte.

description:
The ore hearth is a furnace made of cast-iron blocks, set in brickwork, and used for the reduction of very pure lead ores.
The ore is charged into the hearth with coal or charcoal, and exposed to the action of a blast of warm air supplied from the back of the hearth. A large proportion of the lead is at once reduced at a low temperature and runs off by a narrow channel into a receptacle; the remainder of the charge is raked out and exposed to the air on the “work-stone” in front of the hearth. description:
This continuous revolving furnace, for roasting ores in order to remove arsenic and sulphur, was patented in 1868 by Robert Oxland and John Hocking.
It consists of an iron cylinder, 30 ft. long by 4 ft. diam., lined with firebricks, so arranged that every third or fourth brick in a ring projects 1 in. or more beyond the face of the rest so as to form shelves for the ore. Three or more baffle plates may also be inserted at intervals in the interior. It is supported at an inclination of about 1 in 24 by cast-iron rings on anti-friction rollers, and is rotated by bevel gear. A furnace is placed at the lower end, and the upper end is placed in connection with condensing chambers (not shown). The dressed ore previously dried over the chamber is fed through a hopper into the upper end of the cylinder, which is rotated at a speed of about 1 rev. in 4 mins. The ore slowly travels down, dropping off the shelves through the flames, and experiencing as it does so a gradually increasing temperature; the fumes given off are drawn upwards with the products of combustion by chimney draught through flues and falls into one of two closed chambers next the fire.
The furnace, with slight modifications, has met with a wide application; mechanical stirring of the charge on fixed beds is a later method of obtaining a similar result. Inv.

object_name: MODEL OF REVERBERATORY FURNACE FOR LEAD SMELTING
description: The model, after Karsten, has two flat beds superimposed, the lower one only being provided with a firegrate. The lead ores were first heated and partially roasted on the upper bed, where they were dried and partially roasted. They were then raked on to the lower bed, where the roasting was completed. The fume was led into a brick chamber containing partitions, and was then allowed to escape at the roof.
interpretation: This furnace, although obsolete, is of interest as a forerunner of the modern types of “multiple hearth” furnaces, largely used in present-day roasting operations.

description: This plant was in use at the Wanlockhead lead mines of the Duke of Buccleuch for arresting the solid particles contained in the fume or smoke from the “hearths.” It consists of a rectangular building of masonry, about 30 ft. high, divided by a partition into two chambers, in one of which are eight baffle plates, past which the fume from eight furnaces travels four times while meeting a shower of water from a reservoir at the top of the building. The fume then passes through a grating, 2 ft. wide, filled with coke washed by water, and, finally, down the other charged intermittently by a gridiron slide valve reciprocated by a water-wheel, which also pumps the water back to the tank on top. The fume so arrested is collected in slime pits, and contains about 33 per cent. of lead with 4·5 oz. of silver to the ton.
interpretation: This plant was used for arresting the solid particles contained in the fume or smoke from the hearths. The fume arrested contains lead and silver.

collection: SECTIONAL MODELS OF SMALL SAXONY BLAST FURNACES
object_name: SECTIONAL MODELS OF SMALL SAXONY BLAST FURNACES
description: Scale 1:16. One of these is a single furnace and the other a double one; such furnaces were formerly employed at Freiberg for the reduction of impure argentiferous lead ores. The shafts are rectangular, and the hearths are moulded from a mixture of coke-dust and clay in the form of a basin, in which the reduced metal collects, and is tapped off at intervals of 6 hrs. into a depression at a lower level; a dam is provided over which the slag flows continuously. collection: MODELS OF POTS FOR PATTINSON’S PROCESS
object_name: MODELS OF POTS FOR PATTINSON’S PROCESS
description: MODELS OF POTS FOR PATTINSON’S PROCESS. (Scale 1:12.) Lent by the Commissioners for the Exhibition of 1851. Plate IX, No. 2, p. 34. Lent by the Commissioners for the Exhibition of 1851. In this process, patented in 1833 by Mr. H. L. Pattinson, advantage is taken of the liquation that occurs when argentiferous lead cools. The alloy that first solidifies contains less silver than that remaining liquid. To illustrate the process, three pots out of a series of ten used at Wanlockhead mines are shown. These are of metal, of cast iron, each set over a fireplace. The lead smelted in the hearths is placed in the centre pot, and melted by a fire beneath the working platform. It is then allowed to cool somewhat, when the “crystals” of lead that are first formed are fished out by means of a perforated ladle and transferred to the empty pot on the right hand, while the enriched residue is then transferred to the left-hand pot. A fresh portion is then treated and the operation repeated at each pot, a small quantity of very rich silver-lead being obtained from the pot at the extreme left hand of the series, while the bulk of the lead, which passes to the extreme right-hand pot of the series, contains no appreciable quantity of silver. The smaller pots, each with its own firegrate, seem immediately in front of the model, are to receive the ladles and to keep them at the same temperature as the pots. Inv. 1885-171, 21538.

description: (Scale 1 : 16.) This model shows a furnace arranged for the oxidation of argentiferous lead at a low temperature, the resulting litharge flowing away in the molten state, whilst the residual silver is allowed to solidify on the bed, and is removed after the lifting off of the roof of the furnace. The foundation is of masonry, provided with air channels to keep it cool, and bound together by iron ties. It supports a shallow bed of brickwork of a distorted oval shape, and is subsequently covered with a layer of marl to enable it to withstand the solvent action of litharge. Over the test is an iron "hat," hung from the end of a lever crane, so that it can be readily raised or lowered when required. Its under surface is lined with a mixture of clay and straw, held in place by jagged pieces of iron attached to the framing of the hat. There is an opening at the left-hand side of the furnace through which the pigs of lead are inserted, and a larger opening immediately in front through which the lead oxide or litharge flows, and which also serves as an outlet for the gases. The furnace is heated to the low temperature required by means of a grate on the right-hand side, burning pine wood, whilst blasts of air coming alternately from two nozzles that project through the wall assist the otherwise very feeble draught of the fire. The silver cake produced contains lead and is far from pure; it is allowed to solidify before the hat is lifted for its removal.

description: (Scale 1 : 16.) This differs in several important respects from No. 73; the firegrate is larger, the laboratory part or bed is smaller, and the furnace is connected to a chimney, so that the temperature obtained is much higher. There is only one blast pipe for supplying air to the surface of the bath of metal, and the opening for it is close to the chimney. The furnace is similar in other respects to No. 73, but, on account of the higher temperature obtained and the more porous nature of the bed, the silver refined by it is purer. The bed is capable of holding half a ton of refined metal. Inv. 1894-206.

description: This model represents a special furnace, which differs somewhat from the one in general use under the above name. The bed consists of a removable iron frame that can be filled with bone-ash. This bone-ash bed, or "test," not only resists the action of the molten litharge, but also absorbs it to a marked degree. The test is placed under a fixed roof, and the excess of litharge is allowed to flow through a hole in the test into a small ladle on wheels placed below. The model represents the iron casting of the furnace only; it is provided with a grate on the left-hand side, from which the test is heated, and a nozzle behind for the supply of air, with a working door in front for inspection. The lead is first melted in an exterior vessel, and allowed to run on to the test in the molten condition from time to time, being continually oxidised, until towards the end of the operation the charge upon the test is nearly pure silver. The silver, when completely refined in such a furnace, is of a higher degree of purity than that obtained from one with a marl bed. It is either cast direct from the test, or else allowed to cool on the bed.

description: The process followed consists in the exposure of a mixture of zinc oxide and anthracite to a high temperature in a clay retort, from which the metallic zinc reduced then distils. object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF ZINC DISTILLATION FURNACE
description: This illustrates a form of natural-draught crucible furnace employed in purifying zinc by distillation, or for recovering the zinc from the scum produced in the desilverisation of lead by the process, invented in 1850 by Alexander Parkes, involving the addition of zinc to the argentiferous lead, so as to form a scum or alloy of zinc and lead in which nearly all the silver present accumulates. The distillation furnace represented is square in plan and built of firebrick with a cover of fireclay slabs, held in a cast-iron frame, which can be raised by tackle. The plumbago retorts used are in three parts, the crucible, the hood, and the tube, or “allonge,” for conveying the zinc fumes to the condenser. The crucible rests on a plumbago stand and brick pier in the centre of the furnace, and the condensation is performed in a pyramidal cast-iron box, with a removable cover and sight-holes, through which the interior may be examined and the tube cleaned by scraping. The bottom of the crucible having been covered with pieces of charcoal, the interior is packed full of the zinc scum mixed with 1 per cent. of charcoal powder, and the hood and tube are luted on. The furnace is filled with coke and lighted from the top, but the cover is not placed on the condenser until a reducing atmosphere is created by the evolution of carbon monoxide. The distillation then proceeds, and, when completed, the condenser is removed, the hood at the same time being lifted and the rich lead in the bottom of the crucible ladled out into moulds. The working of a charge of 490 lb. takes about 8.5 hrs., and the product is about 50 per cent. of rich lead, 30 per cent. of metallic zinc, and 13 per cent. of scrapings, etc.
interpretation: This illustrates a form of natural-draught crucible furnace employed in purifying zinc by distillation, or for recovering the zinc from the scum produced in the desilverisation of lead by the process, invented in 1850 by Alexander Parkes, involving the addition of zinc to the argentiferous lead, so as to form a scum or alloy of zinc and lead in which nearly all the silver present accumulates.

collection: SPECIMENS ILLUSTRATING THE REGENERATIVE ELECTRO-ZINCING PROCESS.
object_name: SPECIMENS ILLUSTRATING THE REGENERATIVE ELECTRO-ZINCING PROCESS.
description: This series consists of a number of iron and steel objects which have been coated with zinc electrically, together with examples of various zinc deposits, and of zinc dust used in the process. The process was abandoned before hot galvanising, but was gradually overcome on account of the difficulties met with. These difficulties were gradually overcome by further experimenting, and, by the introduction of the regenerative process, the operation was rendered extremely simple. The process consists in placing the articles to be coated in a solution of zinc sulphate, with or without aluminium sulphate; zinc or lead plates are suspended in the bath through which an electric current is conducted into the solution. The zinc plating solution is circulated by means of compressed air, or a centrifugal pump through the depositing tank, and then through a filter bed of broken coke and zinc dust. The zinc dust is dissolved, replacing the zinc that has been electro-deposited on the iron work suspended in the bath. Small articles, such as bolts and nuts, are electro-galvanised by placing them in a revolving drum suspended in the zincing solution.
materials: iron; steel; zinc; aluminium sulphate; lead; coke
interpretation: This series illustrates the regenerative electro-zincing process. The process was initially abandoned due to difficulties but was improved through experimentation and the introduction of a regenerative process, making the operation simple. It details the steps involved in coating iron and steel objects with zinc, including the use of zinc sulphate solutions, electric currents, compressed air or pumps for circulation, filter beds, and a revolving drum for small articles.

description: This exhibit consists of a number of metallic articles which have been coated with zinc by a wholly “dry” process, without the use of any galvanising solution. Iron or steel articles to be dry-galvanised are first pickled in acid, or sand-blasted, to remove scale and oxide. They are then packed in an iron retainer, which is charged with zinc dust, and then closed in such a way as to make it practically airtight. The closed retainer is then heated to a temperature of about 300° C. for several hours. It is then cooled and opened, when the articles are found to be coated with a uniform layer of zinc, the thickness of which depends upon the temperature and the time of heating. It is interesting to note that this result is obtained at a temperature approximately 100 deg. below the melting point of zinc. The method has been applied with success to other metals, such as copper and aluminium, and also to the decoration of metallic surfaces by inlaying. Those parts of the metallic surface upon which no zinc is required are first coated with a protective varnish, or “stopping-off” composition.

description: This furnace is used for tin smelting, and, as the temperature required is high, a tall chimney stack is necessary; the furnace is, moreover, strongly built and held together by screwed tie-bars. The firegrate is of the step type of large size, and is arranged under the same arch that covers the bed, while the fire bridge has an air space through it to assist in cooling it. Two working doors are provided at the side of the furnace and adjacent to the stack; through these the furnace is charged at the commencement of the process, and through a large working door in the end of the furnace the charge is thoroughly rabbled and the slag withdrawn. The bed is made of fireclay and nearly flat, but slopes to a tap-hole in the side of the furnace opposite the working doors. Beneath these is a large receiver, into which the molten tin is collected; the first portion—that is, the part having the lowest melting point—is run from the receiver into a large cast-iron pot, or “kettle.” This kettle has a fire beneath it to keep the tin fluid, while above is a crane by means of which billets of wood, enclosed in an iron cage, are lowered into the molten metal; the currents of steam and gas thus generated pass through the tin and refine it. The refined tin is then ladled out into iron ingot moulds, seen at the back of the model. These furnaces are usually worked in pairs, and the second portion of the tin from this furnace would be transferred to the succeeding charge in the other furnace; the slag receives separate treatment.
interpretation: This furnace is used for tin smelting, and, as the temperature required is high, a tall chimney stack is necessary. The currents of steam and gas thus generated pass through the tin and refine it.

description: (Scale 1 : 12.) Made from drawings prepared in the Museum. This reverberatory tin-smelting furnace, while resembling generally in operation the earlier form (see No. 81), embodies improvements in construction introduced in 1895 by Mr. J. McKillop and Mr. T. F. Ellis at Pulau Brani, Singapore. One difficulty in tin furnace work is that of preventing leakage of the metal, because it remains molten at 260° C., and because of its fluidity and high specific gravity it will pass through minute crevices, causing great trouble in recovery. In the furnace shown leakage is permitted, but is intercepted by a water vault extending below the bridge, the bed and the “flote,” or pot, at the tap-hole, thus completely overcoming the difficulty. In case of a break-out of hot material, pipes through the thick corners of the furnace bed give vents for the steam generated. To facilitate and cheapen repairs the bed, the lining, and the roof are so built that they can be replaced separately without disturbing other parts. The bed is built of brick on edge, carefully laid with dry joints. The transverse rails carrying this are in two parts supported on two longitudinals resting on a central brick pillar. When this is knocked away the whole collapses. The lining is built wholly of headers. The roof is one brick thick and springs off the side walls outside the lining. To take its thrust and weight, T irons, supported by the buckstaves, which are of rails tied together with iron rods, are built into these side walls. The fire bridge is built with an air space running right through, which assists in cooling it. The fuel used is anthracite, charged in through fire doors high up. Clinkering is done through holes in a cast-iron plate below. Tinstone, or stream tin, roasted if required to remove arsenic, is the ore used.

description: This is a forced-draught crucible furnace for metallurgists, jewellers, etc. For convenience the furnace body is in three cylindrical portions; at one side of the middle portion is a hole for inserting the burner, the flames from which strike the crucible, pass down to a depression in the bottom portion, thence pass through vertical holes in the middle portion to an annulus in the top portion, or lid, and finally out at the side. The burner has an air and a gas jet joined side by side, so that they can slide relative to the bunsen tube. The air jet is supplied by a foot blower, and it induces the further air necessary for forced combustion. description: Mr. F. B. Miller Introduced at the Sydney Mint in 1867. This process, introduced by Mr. F. B. Miller at the Sydney Mint in 1867, consists in passing chlorine gas through the molten alloy; the chlorine combines with all other metals present and converts them into chlorides before attacking the gold. The impure gold is melted in a crucible, and, while still in the furnace, a current of chlorine, generated in the usual manner, or, in modern plants, obtained from steel cylinders of the liquefied gas, is passed by means of a clay tube through the liquid mass. Some of the base metals present are volatilised as chlorides, but silver, the chief impurity, is converted into a fusible chloride, which, when the gold has solidified on cooling somewhat, is poured off and cast into slabs, while the gold is again melted and cast into ingots.
interpretation: This process involves passing chlorine gas through molten alloy to purify gold by converting other metals into chlorides. Impure gold is melted, treated with chlorine gas via a clay tube, and then the resulting chlorides and gold are separated. Silver, the main impurity, is converted into a fusible chloride that is poured off. The purified gold is then re-melted and cast into ingots.

collection: MILLER'S APPARATUS FOR REDUCING SILVER CHLORIDE
description: This arrangement was introduced by Mr. F. B. Miller to recover the silver from the slabs of chloride obtained in his process for purifying gold (see No. 89). The slabs are placed in canvas bags in a bath of sodium chloride solution between vertical plates of iron or zinc, arranged in a wooden vat, as illustrated, care being taken to secure good electrical contact between the slabs and the metal plates. Reduction then proceeds, and in about 24 hrs. the silver is reduced to the metallic state in a pulverulent form, the particles being retained in the bags. The reduced silver is washed thoroughly with hot water, melted under a little nitre, and cast into ingots.

description: This furnace, patented in 1877 by Mr. J. Fletcher, was chiefly used for melting brass and similar alloys. It consists of an inner and outer shell of cast iron, the former at the bottom having an internally projecting flange, which supports the firebrick lining. The outer casing, carried on three feet, is provided below with a hinged concave door forming a drop bottom. An air blast, supplied through a pipe with a sluice valve, is introduced at the top of the space between the two shells, and, passing downwards, is heated by otherwise waste heat before it enters the furnace at the annular opening left between the flange of the inner and the bottom of the outer casings. The waste gases from the furnace escape through the upper side opening, which, if more convenient, communicate with a stack giving sufficient draught without the use of a fan. At the conclusion of the work the fuel and clinker are quickly removed by knocking out the cotter that retains the drop bottom. The crucible, which is machine-moulded, is formed of a mixture of fireclay and plumbago by which more meltings can be resisted than is possible with those of fireclay only. The salamander is a perforated support of the same material, by means of which the crucible is maintained in the hottest part of the furnace, and also protected from the injurious action of the entering blast. A few inches of coke are, however, necessary between the two appliances.

description: This coke-fired furnace, for melting iron, brass, and the precious metals in crucibles, was patented in 1880 by Mr. Charles Carr, and improved in 1894 by Mr. J. J. W. Carr. The furnace casing is of plate iron with angle irons at the corners extending downward to form feet. The firebrick lining, which is in one piece, rests on a cast-iron plate a few inches above the firebars, thus leaving space for the admission of air over as well as between them; the space between the casing and the lining is filled with some non-conducting material. The side flue, by which the furnace is connected with the chimney to give the necessary draught, is similarly constructed in one block, and is carried by cast-iron plates, dovetailed together and forming a bracket. The crucible and stand used are shown on an adjacent pedestal.

object_name: SPECIMENS ILLUSTRATING THE MANUFACTURE OF GOLD-LEAF
description: The art of gold-beating is an extremely ancient one, having been in existence at least 4,000 years ago, since gold has been found with Egyptian remains. With the progression of time, the art of beating thinner gold has been discovered, and yet thinner gold leaf is produced, but the process as used to-day differs but little from that employed by the ancient Egyptians. The process requires very little machinery, and that only in the initial stages, the greater part of this process requiring only the skilful use of a hand hammer. The process consists essentially of the following stages:— The fine gold is alloyed with a proportion of copper and silver, to give the desired colour and quality of leaf. This alloy is melted and cast into a bar, which is gradually reduced by rolling, with frequent annealing, to a “ribbon,” 1⅛ in. wide, and 2 yards in length to the ounce. This ribbon is then cut into square pieces, each piece weighing 6 grains, and placed between the leaves of a “cutch” (consisting of 200 sheets of parchment prepared from animal matter), measuring 4 in. square. The “cutch” is bound with parchment bands and beaten for about 30 min. with a 20-lb. hammer, until each square of gold ribbon has become as large as the “cutch.” The leaves of gold are now removed from the sheets of parchment paper, quartered with a “skewing” knife, and the quarters placed between the skins of a “shoder” (containing 800 rather coarse strong skins of 4½ in. square). The “shoder” requires 2 hrs. careful beating; for this purpose a 12-lb. hammer is used, and the beating is continued until the quarter leaves have spread to the edges of the skins. They are again cut into quarters, this time with a sharpened reed, and the quarters placed between the skins of a “mould” (composed of 1,000 very thin sheets of gold-beaters’ skin, 5⅛ in. square; these 1,000 skins measure less than 1 in. in thickness and weigh but a few ounces). The “mould” requires some 5 hrs. beating with an 8-lb. hammer. It is in this final beating that the quality of the finished leaf is determined, and the greatest skill on the part of the beater is required. The beating is done on solid blocks of marble, some of which are centuries old, handed down from generation to generation of gold-beaters. Here and there there are the deep holes formed in the marble by the mere pressure of the thumb of the worker as he holds down the mould. When the leaves are beaten to the required size and thinness, they are removed from the skins, placed singly on a calf-skin cushion and trimmed to size with sharpened reeds fixed in a small frame called a “waggon,” and afterwards placed between the sheets of thin paper books. From the “ribbon” stage until the finished leaves are in books the gold is never touched by the hand, but manipulated with boxwood pincers. To illustrate the malleability of gold, it may be stated that 12 dwts. will produce 2,500 leaves. Were it possible to beat 1 oz. into a single sheet, it would measure about 250 sq. ft. The exhibit illustrates the successive stages in the process, and comprises :— (1) Bar of gold as cast. (2) Ribbon produced by rolling from a similar bar, and ribbon cut in squares. (3) Portion of a cutch, showing gold interleaved. (4) Beaten cutch and quarters produced from same. (5) Shoder with cutch quarters interleaved. (6) Beaten shoder and quarters produced from same. (7) Mould with shoder quarters interleaved. (8) Beaten mould. (9) Gold-leaf in books. (10) Hammers used in the process. (11) Cutting waggon. (12) Skewing knife. (13) Parchment bands. (14) Pincers. (1925-200).

description: The ovens are a series of low vaults placed back to back; each row is provided with a railway and each oven with a charging aperture in its roof. The fronts are temporarily closed with brickwork and only enough air is admitted to burn the volatile products; these supply the necessary heat, and the products of their combustion escape by a chimney that is provided to each pair of ovens. When the coke is finished, it is withdrawn in one mass by the aid of an iron drag that is placed in a groove in the floor before charging; this drag is hauled out by means of a chain operated by a steam capstan. When brought on to the cooling floor the coke is quenched by water from a hose; the coking usually occupies from 36 to 48 hrs.

object_name: MODEL OF COKE-OVEN AND BYE-PRODUCT PLANT.
description: (Scale 1:12.) Lent by Messrs. Newton Chambers & Co. This oven is of the “beehive” type, but adapted for the recovery of bye-products by modifications patented by Messrs. A. M. Chambers & T. Smith in 1884–89. The air for combustion is heated by passing it through a circular flue or pipe round the oven and discharging it in an upward direction over the fuel, which is ignited by contact with the hot ovens on either side; by making channels through the fuel, “smudge,” or fine coal, can be converted. The floor of the oven is inclined and is made of slotted tiles; it is supported on dwarf walls, rising from a floor of still greater slope, so that the liquid products collected below drain into a well. The gaseous products pass through a tubular condenser, scrubbers, air condensers, etc., from which the uncondensed gas is led off for use in raising steam. The condensed liquor is treated with lime and steam, to drive off ammonia, which is absorbed by sulphuric acid and converted into ammonium sulphate. The condensed oil is distilled, washed and otherwise treated, so as to give oils for illuminating and lubricating purposes, wax and pitch, besides a red-brown oxy-hydro-carbon of specific gravity 1.04, which is further treated for the manufacture of disinfectant, etc.

description: The class of oven, of which this is a leading example, have means whereby all the gases produced are drawn off from the coking chamber and deprived of their valuable constituents; they are then returned to the oven and burnt in flues in order to supply the heat necessary for coking. Owing to no air being admitted to the coking chamber, loss by the combustion of the coke is avoided. The model represents one of the series of chambers, which may be 30 or 40 in number. The coking chamber is charged, from two apertures in the roof, with coal brought over the range in railway trucks. The oven heated from the previous charge at once causes the gases to be evolved freely, and they are conducted by the pipe A to a gas works plant to be deprived of their tar and ammonia. They are then brought back along the pipe B, and burnt in a small chamber immediately beneath the oven, giving a flame that passes right along a flue beneath the coking space, thence by horizontal flues in one of the side walls, and then to one or other of two chimney flues (at the extreme end of the model), which traverse the entire length of the range. The flame from the space beneath the next oven in the series passes to the second chimney, and so on, alternate fires being connected to one flue. The air necessary for the combustion of the gas first traverses the outer tunnel of the series of five, then the next, the central one, and finally the inner one, from which each of the gas flames are supplied by a cross flue running beneath the whole length of the combustion chamber. The air is thus well heated, at the same time, prevents the foundation and the brickwork becoming overheated. The ovens are charged alternately at equal intervals; when the charge is completely coked, it is pushed out at the slightly larger end in one mass by an iron ram from the other end, the ram being worked by a small locomotive steam winch. A set of rails is laid down parallel to the range, to enable the winch to operate upon all the ovens in succession, whilst each coking chamber is provided with iron doors at its ends for the same purpose. The space over the tunnels forms a cooling floor, on which the hot coke can be quenched in the usual way. Usually a small fire, which is made up once in 12 hrs., is kept burning on the grate.

description: (Scale 1: 12.) Presented by Sir C. W. Siemens, F.R.S. One of the essentials of the invention patented by Messrs. C. W. & F. Siemens in 1861 is that the fuel be decomposed in a separate generator so as to avoid the employment of solid fuel into the furnace. Small coal is fed through covered apertures into the generating chamber, and rests in a thick layer upon a brick slope and a step-grate, seen in section in the model. The lower part of the grate forms a water-trough, the steam from which assists the combustion on the grate and forms the so-called "water-gas" (carbonic oxide and hydrogen), which enriches the simple "producer-gas" (carbonic oxide and nitrogen). The gas as it is generated is collected from the producer by means of the tunnel, seen in the left-hand side of the model, from which it rises and passes along a horizontal cooling pipe and then down to the furnace, the difference in the weight of the hot and the cooled columns giving the required draught; gas-producers of the present day are, however, almost invariably provided with a closed ash-pit worked by a slightly forced draught. Apertures, covered with iron spheres, are provided in the roof of the producer, through which an iron bar introduced to break down the coal from time to time, and maintain the dense uniform condition necessary for good working.

description: This sectional model, formerly the property of the late Sir C. W. Siemens, represents a modified type of Siemens gas-producer of circular form, which is worked with a closed bottom and a steam jet. The coal is fed into the generating chamber through a hopper placed in the centre of the roof of the producer, the hopper being closed by a bell, which also acts as a fuel distributor. The firebars are placed horizontally so as to give a large grate area. The ash-pit is divided into two parts by a transverse wall from the centre of which a cone projects upwards into the generating chamber, and through this cone steam and air are discharged into the centre of the fuel. The upper part of the producer is of conical shape, and openings in the bottom of the cone allow of the escape of the gas into the annular gas chamber surrounding the cone. description: MODEL OF WILSON GAS-PRODUCER. (Scale 1: 12.) Made from drawings prepared in the Museum. This producer was patented in 1876 by Messrs. E. Brook & A. Wilson, and was a distinct advance on existing types, embodying as it did a retort portion, an open hearth without firebars, and forced draught. At first the producer was built rectangular in plan, but about 1880 the octagonal form was adopted and the brickwork enclosed in a cylindrical shell of wrought iron, to which doors, etc., could be attached, a construction now universal. The producer is placed in a convenient situation for bringing coal to the level of the staging. The "slack" coal is fed through a hopper into the retort, which is in the form of a conical curtain wall, the intention being that the heavier hydrocarbons before reaching the exit holes leading to an annular chamber surrounding the retort, and thus avoid the subsequent deposition of tar in the gas main. The rate of combustion is regulated by the action of an injector, consisting of a steam jet opposite the narrow throat of a tapered vertical pipe. The mixture, in the proportion by weight of about 1 of steam to 20 of air, is delivered at a pressure of 1 to 3 in. of water to a rectangular tuyère, which has three openings at each side in the centre of the hearth, the most economical point. Incomplete combustion takes place with the formation of carbon monoxide; part of the heat evolved, however, is absorbed by the decomposition of the steam. This takes place near the tuyères, keeping that region cool and rendering the clinker brittle. The latter is raked out at intervals of about 24 hrs. through two doors, one on each side of the tuyère, supported by a number of iron bars, driven by belting. This operation requires about half an hour, the producer being shut down meanwhile by the closure of a damper. The gas produced passes off at a temperature of about 430° C. by a pipe leading from the annular chamber, either through a downcomer to an underground flue, or through brick-lined tubes above ground. The average composition of the gas by volume is: CO 24 per cent. ; CO 12.5 per cent. H ; 3.5 per cent. other combustible gases; 5 per cent. CO₂ and 55 per cent. N. About 140,000 cub. ft. are produced for each ton of fuel. The size of the producer shown would gasify upwards of 8 cwt. of coal per hour, or at the rate of about 25 lb. of fuel per sq. ft. of hearth area—i.e., double the rate of Siemens' sloping grate producer. In 1882 Mr. Wilson introduced a new form of producer, in which the fuel was continuously and automatically supplied while the ash was similarly removed by screw conveyors, thus dispensing with labour.

description: Made in the Museum from information supplied by The Power-Gas Corporation, Ltd. This shows a plant for making producer gas regeneratively, and recovering the ammonia, the product being suitable for power purposes in large gas engines. An inferior grade of bituminous coal, such as "slack" or "dross," is discharged direct from railway wagons into a well, whence it is raised by an elevator and distributed by conveyors to each row of three producers. The fuel is admitted by sliding nets and measuring hoppers to the producers, which are of the form patented in 1893 by Dr. Ludwig Mond, F.R.S.; each consists of a double wrought-iron shell, lined with firebrick, the lower part of the inner shell being formed as a conical grate, and that of the outer shell made to dip into a water seal. Heated air and steam are blown through the annular space between the shells and through the grate, the reaction with the fuel resulting in the formation of hydrogen, carbon monoxide, marsh gas, and a trace of ammonia, diluted with nitrogen and carbon dioxide. The heat evolved is, to a great extent, regenerated, and it is in this direction that the Mond system is an advance on previous practice. The ashes sink into the water seal and are raked out at intervals without stopping the production of gas. The temperature of working is kept low, as this is favourable to the production of ammonia and unfavourable to the clinkering of the ash; this is done by using a weight of steam 2.5 times the weight of fuel gasified, but a weight equal to that of the fuel is subsequently recovered. Where the fuel consumed is less than 30 tons per 24 hrs., the expense of ammonia recovery plant is not usually incurred. In that case the weight of steam used is limited to that of the fuel gasified. After leaving the producer the gas passes through a regenerator, which is simply a series of jacketed tubes, the blast of air and steam being in the jacket and the gas inside. It is then delivered to a mechanical washer in the space between the producers. This is a rectangular wrought-iron chamber, where the gas is met by fine spray thrown up by rapidly revolving dashers, driven by belting. The heat of the gas is rendered latent by the formation of steam at a temperature of about 90° C., and the dust and soot, etc., washed out. The tar are removed by an arrangement of lutes in the sides of the washers. The gas then ascends the acid tower through chequer brickwork, over which falls a shower of sulphuric acid in weak solution, the ammonia combining with it to form ammonium sulphate. The acid solution is kept circulating till it contains 36 to 38 per cent. of this salt, when a small stream of the liquor is allowed to run off and is made up by fresh supplies of sulphuric acid. The gas is next passed to the bottom of the gas-cooling tower, where it is met by cold water trickling over wood packing. The water vapour with which it is charged condenses, and this, together with the water that has been used, is pumped to the top of the air-heating tower, where it serves to warm and saturate the air blast on the way to the producers, and is thereby cooled sufficiently for use over again in the gas-cooling tower. A separate building is set apart for the concentration of the ammonium sulphate liquor, after being neutralised, it enters conical vacuum evaporators, heated by steam at 35-lb. pressure in coils of lead piping; the crystals, after being drained, are dried by a hydro-extractor. The quantity realised is about 90 lb. per ton of fuel gasified, but varies with the kind of coal used. There is a power-house to accommodate the Roots blower, water and acid circulating pumps, and an engine for driving the washer. The plant represented is for gasifying 120 tons of fuel per 24 hrs.; 1 ton will produce about 150,000 cub. ft. of gas at ordinary temperature and pressure. About 60 cub. ft. are required to develop one indicated h.p. in a large gas engine.

description:
This represents a mechanically operated producer, fitted with the floating agitator for the fuel bed, patented by W. B. Chapman in 1920.
In the forced-draught stationary producer the method of charging the fuel by hopper and bell tends to uneven distribution, which, although counteracted by hand poking, leads to the formation of thin places in the bed and consequent hot spots, hence a reduction in the quality of the gas. This has led to the design of mechanical producers whose essential features are:—
(1) Automatic charging of fuel in small quantities at a time.
(2) Agitation of the fuel bed to prevent the formation of holes.
(3) Automatic removal of the ashes and clinker.
At first these conditions were met by rotating slowly the whole producer, e.g., in the Chapman producer of 1909 there were two portions revolving at slightly different rates, and a counter-balanced “slicing” tube, or rakes, were relied upon for distribution. The next step was to rotate the agitator, as shown, and keep the fuel bed stationary.
The Chapman agitator has a double helix at the upper end that slides vertically in, and is driven by reduction worm gearing from an electric motor at a speed of 1 rev. in 7 mins. By this device, should there be any obstruction, it will rise and pass over it; it will also accommodate itself to varying depths of fuel bed. From the T arm depend six or more fingers, set forward in the direction of rotation. It is found necessary to make these renewable, of carbon steel, and the tube itself of weldless steel. All parts are water-cooled, there being an internal pipe circulation with an outlet at each finger.
The fuel is fed by a hopper into a drum, which has three pockets, each holding 50 to 60 lb. of coal. As the pockets rotate, actuated by a lever and ratchet, they act as coal crushers and discharge into an internal distributing chute. The feed can be varied from zero to 6,000 lb. per hour.
An agitator can be fitted to existing stationary producers, and it is claimed that an increased gasification, varying from 50 per cent. in the poorest grade of fuel to 100 per cent. with producer coal containing 10 per cent. of ash, will be obtained; the quality of the gas will be uniform and a saving in labour will be realised, offset against which must be placed the capital cost of the installation.

description: The influence of hot surfaces in promoting chemical changes in gaseous mixtures at temperatures below their actual ignition points was noticed as early as 1816 by Sir Humphry Davy. The phenomena were examined by others, but no industrial application of value was made till Professor W. G. Bone, F.R.S., found that the accelerating influence of hot surfaces extended to temperatures above ignition point, combination taking place still without flame. Means for utilising this property in practice, patented in 1909 and subsequently, by Professor Bone, Mr. J. W. Wilson, and Mr. C. D. McCourt, are shown. A diaphragm of refractory material is mounted to form one boundary of a mixing chamber, into which coal gas and excess of air is introduced. The gases burn without flame within a surface layer which is restricted by the cooling effect of the interstices through which the gases have to pass and by the inflow of the cold mixture, to a thickness of about 0.1 in., unless the temperature exceeds about 850° C. A series of diaphragms are shown. The first kind was made of fireclay, mixed with rape seed and burnt. Later the porosity was increased by making the diaphragm of ground firebrick or of firebrick pellets fritted together. One of the latter is shown, mounted in its frame. Where the heat is not radiated quickly and the temperature exceeds 850° C., e.g., in metallurgical and boiler furnaces, an alternative method, patented in 1910, is used, and consists in burning the mixture on the surface of an assemblage of refractory fragments. The mixture must be supplied at a speed in excess of its speed of ignition.

description:
This model represents a plant for the extraction of silver from argentiferous copper regulus by either Zierroogel's or Augustin's method.
For the former process the ore, which has previously been carefully roasted in order to convert the silver into soluble sulphate, and, at the same time, eliminate ferrous sulphate, is charged into a tub provided with a filter bottom and a tap. The tub is on wheels, which run on a tramway in order to facilitate removal, and is placed at the upper level of the room so that no subsequent pumping of liquid is necessary. Hot water is supplied to the ore from a tank heated by a small furnace, seen on the right of the model, and, after percolating through the mass, is drawn off and led by launders or channels to the set of wooden tubs or tanks, seen at successive lower levels. In these the silver is first deposited on metallic copper, and then in the lowest tanks of all the copper is precipitated on metallic iron. The resulting liquid containing ferrous sulphate is then allowed to flow away to waste, and the charge of spent ore is thrown down the shoot, seen on the left hand of the model, which delivers it into a truck for subsequent treatment.
Augustin's process is conducted in precisely the same way, except that the ore is first roasted with salt and afterwards leached with hot brine.
The silver obtained by these processes is in a granular or “ cement” form, and is usually made into cakes under a hydraulic press, and then melted and cast into ingots of 1,000 oz. each.

description: The process here represented is obsolete, but its machinery is interesting as forming a link between that of the old “Mexican” process and the modern system of pan-amalgamation. The silver ore, previously finely ground and then roasted with salt in a reverberatory furnace, was delivered to hoppers, seen in the upper part of the model. Portions were from time to time then charged to the wooden barrel, seen beneath, with a little mercury and some water, together with metallic copper or iron from the latter in the form of old cannon balls. The barrels were of oak, bound with iron and mounted on horizontal axes, about which they were rotated by gearing. When charged, the filling hole was was closed and the barrel rotated at about 22 revs. per min. for 24 hrs. by means of a water-wheel. The resulting mixture of mud and amalgam was drawn off from the barrel and the bulk of the fluid amalgam diverted; the remainder was conducted through a grid to strain off pieces of iron, and then down to the settling tank, seen at the base of the model. Here it was gently stirred with much water by the frames that were attached to the slowly rotating vertical shaft, and after a period the liquid was drawn off from the top in successive layers. Finally, the residue of the amalgam was collected from the settling tub and distilled; the purer amalgam withdrawn at the first was distilled by itself, after it had been strained through canvas or leather.

description: Scale 1: 48. Made in the Museum from particulars supplied by the Dorr Company, per Messrs. Fraser & Chalmers Engineering Works. The cyanide process is based on the solubility of gold and silver in solutions of potassium or sodium cyanide. The first commercial application was made in 1887–88 by Mr. J. S. MacArthur, R. W. Forrest, and W. Forrest. This was a plant for treating gold ore, erected in 1887 at the Crown Mine, Karangahake, Thames District, New Zealand, and it was closely followed in 1890 by one on the Witwatersrand Goldfields, South Africa. The plant was of the simplest description, consisting of vats with double bottoms, covered with coconut matting, on which the crushed ore rested, and through which the cyanide solution percolated. The leached ore was removed at first by spade work, but later through a manhole in the bottom of the tank. The filter press was introduced for washing out the remaining cyanide solution from the residue ore. Since then developments of the process have been in the direction of making it continuous, coupled with improvements in the mechanical appliances and with agitation by air. The model represents a counter-current decantation plant on the Dorr system, the first application of which was in 1906 at Mogul Mill, Black Hills, South Dakota. It is arranged on the "step" plan, which is adopted when, as is often the case, local configuration of the ground does not lend itself to gravitational flow. The plant consists of a series of thickener and agitator tanks, operated in such a manner that thick pulp from the tube mills with a small amount of fresh cyanide solution, made up in volume with clear water, passes successively from one tank to another in series. Barren solution from the precipitation boxes flows in the contrary direction, so that by dilution and decantations the ore is gradually leached of its gold contents while the solution is correspondingly enriched. The thickener, patented in 1917 by Mr. J. van N. Dorr, consists of a circular tank, 45 ft. diam. by 14 ft. deep, with a perforated peripheral launder that collects the solution overflowing at the top. The pulp from the mill is delivered into a short central vertical shaft, provided with a central vertical shaft, provided with a worm gear at the rate of 1 rev. in 10 mins. These arms carry ploughs, set at an angle of about 12 deg. to the horizontal, which push the thickened pulp to a discharge opening in the bottom of the tank. The shaft and arms can be raised by means of a lifting yoke to avoid being set fast in the thickened pulp when it is necessary to shut down. The pulp is elevated from the bottom discharge by "Dorrco" adjustable stroke duplex diaphragm pumps, mounted between the tanks on staging, which supports the necessary driving shafts, etc. The speed of the pumps with a 3-in. stroke is 40 r.p.m. The agitator, patented in 1915 by Mr. Dorr, consists of a tank, 25 ft. diam. by 16 ft. deep, with a central vertical cylinder, carried by a shaft supported from the top of the tank and having two radial arms, fitted with ploughs. These arms are hinged so that they can be adjusted to a suitable angle to make the pulp travel slowly towards the centre, where it is raised by compressed air through the vertical cylinder to the revolving launders and distributed uniformly over the surface of the pulp. The speed of these launders is about 5 r.p.m., and they require 0.5 to 0.75 h.p.; 10 to 15 cub. ft. of compressed air per minute at 20-lb. pressure is required. The solution flows into No. 1 thickener, and thence into Nos. 1 and 2 agitators, when the solution of the gold in the pulp is in general completed. The function of the last four thickeners is to wash out the gold-bearing cyanide solution from the solids before they are discharged as tailings from tank No. 5. Make-up clear water, in amount equal to the loss of liquid in the tailings, is added to the last tank along with the barren solution from the precipitation boxes. The overflow from No. 5 thickener passes to No. 4, thence through No. 3 and No. 2 into the small tank solution sump and storage tank. The solution overflows from No. 1 thickener and storage tank to the precipitation boxes, which are shown in a separate model (see No. 107). From 2 lb. to 20 lb. of KCN are required per ton of ore treated, depending on the time of agitation, which varies considerably with different ores. The tonnage output per 24 hrs. with ore of sp. gr. 2·65 in the dry state ranges from about 320 tons with 40 per cent. solution to 160 tons with 75 per cent. solution. A diagram, showing the whole arrangement of mill and cyanide plant, is exhibited.

object_name: MODEL OF PRECIPITATION BOXES FOR CYANIDE PLANT
description: This represents the usual form of boxes used in the cyanide process (see No. 106). The apparatus consists of a long box, or trough, supported on bearers at a slight inclination and divided into cells, from one to another of which the gold-bearing solution from the cyanide plant overflows in series, as shown partly sectioned, one baffle compartment and six cells. The construction is generally of wood obtained locally; this is framed with panels and diaphragms, the whole being tongued, grooved and bolted together with tie-rods, 1 in. diam. The baffle compartment at the intake end is for the purpose of giving solid matter time to settle before the solution enters the cells proper. Each cell is filled with metallic zinc in the form of shavings to expose as large a surface as possible for precipitation. These shavings rest on a wire screen, supported in turn on ledges, leaving a space underneath for sludge, the direction of flow being upward to facilitate deposition. The bottom slopes to the front, where there is a plug to discharge the sludge at intervals into the trough. The barren solution from the last cell is returned to the cyanide plant. The zinc is subsequently treated by distillation to get out the gold.

object_name: PHOTO-MICROGRAPHS OF SECTIONS OF IRON AND STEEL
description: This set of 10 photo-micrographs represents some of the first work done in the examination of the micro-structure of iron and steel. Dr. Sorby was the pioneer in this work, which he carried on at University College, Sheffield, and the modern science of metallography has largely grown from the results of Dr. Sorby's work. Strong surface illumination was used in producing the photographs, which show structures due to the arrangement of crystals of iron, combined with a varying amount of carbon, of portions of slag, and of crystalline plates of graphite. The contrast between the structure of cast iron, cast steel, and meteoric iron should be noted.

description: The series of 24 photo-micrographs illustrate types of crystal structure shown by non-ferrous metals and alloys. Nos. 1 and 3 show the solidified surfaces of a pure metal and an alloy respectively and exhibit the fern-like (dendritic) structure frequently met with in crystalline substances, such as ice and snow crystals. The rest of the series consists of photo-micrographs of sections of metals, polished and etched to reveal their internal structure. No. 2 is typical of a pure metal. Each grain represents an individual crystal which has been prevented from developing its natural external shape owing to the growth of its neighbours. Nos. 4-21 illustrate typical structures met with in different alloys. Some of these alloys are of considerable industrial importance. Nos. 22 and 23 show the way in which metal crystals deform in the process of rolling, drawing, etc. Blocks of the metal slide over each other along definite crystallographic planes and in definite directions. No. 24 exhibits the selective etching of copper by evaporation, which takes place more easily in certain planes than in others.

collection: TOUCHSTONE FOR THE ASSAY OF GOLD
object_name: Touchstone for the Assay of Gold
description: This is a specimen of the stone formerly used for the "Trial by the Touch," which is the oldest method of assay of gold bullion, and is still of service in particular cases. The method of assay consists in rubbing the gold bullion to be tested on the hard smooth surface of the stone, and comparing the appearance and colour of the streak with those made by prepared needles of known composition. The effect of nitric acid on these streaks is also noted. Touchstones usually consist of Lydianstone, or Trap, and are preferably dark green or black. The trial is more accurate for alloys below 750 fine (or 75 per cent.) than for higher standards.

description: This is a hand-crushing appliance for the reduction of ores to a fine state of division as a preliminary to their assay by fire methods. The appliance consists of a hardened steel plate, with a carefully machined surface, and a muller, of hardened steel, of hemi-cylindrical form, provided with a handle, and weighing about 60 lb. The ore is placed upon the plate in small quantities at a time, and the muller is moved by hand, with a combined rocking and reciprocating motion, over its surface. As the ore is gradually crushed finer, it is brushed off the plate and passed through a sieve, the oversize being returned to the plate for further crushing. The process is continued until all the ore is crushed to the desired size. If the ore is in large pieces, or if many samples are to be crushed, a machine grinder is usually employed.
interpretation: This is a hand-crushing appliance for the reduction of ores to a fine state of division as a preliminary to their assay by fire methods.

description: This crusher is of considerable utility for the hand reduction of small quantities of ore; it will deal with material varying in size from 0.5 in. pieces to coarse powder. The crusher consists of a hardened steel cylindrical trough, with a central upright projection, tapered and ribbed. In this trough is placed a heavy cylindrical steel muller, provided with a central ribbed aperture, through which passes the upright projection of the trough, when the muller is placed in position. Pieces of ore are placed in the "jaws" of the crusher thus formed, and the muller is given an oscillating motion by means of the handles to start the crushing. The muller is then rotated by means of one of the handles, the other being detached. As the ore becomes reduced in size it descends through the annular "jaws," and passes under the muller, where it is ground fine, and is discharged by an opening on the periphery of the trough.
interpretation: This crusher is of considerable utility for the hand reduction of small quantities of ore.

description: This is a small jaw-crusher, particularly designed for hand operation, and patented by Messrs. F. W. Braun in 1902. The crusher is made of cast iron throughout, with the exception of the jaw-plates, which are of hardened steel. It consists essentially of two jaw-plates, one fixed and the other capable of a reciprocating motion, imparted by a hand wheel through an eccentric. The plates are inclined to one another, the space between them at their lower edges being regulated by a hand screw. Lumps of ore are fed into the jaws at their upper extremity, and on rotating the handle the product, crushed to 0.25 in. size or smaller, falls into a suitable receptacle. A 0.5-h.p. motor can be used in place of the hand drive.

description: This is a jaw-crusher, patented by Messrs. F. W. Braun in 1905 and improved in 1912. The crusher closely resembles the "Simplex," but is of stronger construction, and is more particularly adapted for a power drive. The crusher frame is of steel, each side plate being in one piece, both being held together by the bearing casting, the front spacer casting, and the toggle block. The vibratory jaw is mounted on an eccentric at its upper end, and rests against a toggle at its lower end. The eccentric imparts a circular movement to the upper end, while the toggle compels the lower end to describe an arc of a small circle; this motion is forward and downward, and impels the discharge. The adjustment of the space between the jaws at the lower ends is made by means of a hand screw.

description:
Lent by Messrs. J. J. Griffin & Sons, Ltd. These are examples of furnace tools and appliances used in the fire assays of lead, gold, and silver.
The crucibles shown are of the type commonly used in gold, silver, and lead assays. The ore, with the necessary fluxes, is melted down in a crucible, and when all is fluid the charge is poured into a compartment in a previously dried assay mould.
Scorifiers are shallow clay dishes in which ores are heated in contact with metallic lead. Part of the lead becomes oxidised and dissolves the impurities in the ore, while the gold and silver are collected in the residual unoxidised lead. The charge is poured when the process is completed.
The cupels shown are of bone-ash, and are used for the separation of gold and silver from metallic lead. Metallic lead is melted in these cupels, which absorb the lead oxide as fast as it is formed, eventually leaving the gold and silver as a bead.
A muffle is the chamber in a muffle furnace in which the operations of scorification, cupellation, and, less frequently, pot-fusion are carried out. The muffle is heated externally by coke, gas, or oil.
The tongs shown include crucible tongs, for lifting crucibles from the furnace and pouring their contents into moulds; scorifier tongs, for the removal of scorifiers from the muffle and pouring their contents; and cupel tongs, for handling cupels. The actual method of handling is illustrated with the crucibles, etc., themselves.
The cupel tray is a small sheet-iron tray, divided into compartments, and provided with a wooden handle for the reception of red-hot cupels as they are taken from the muffle.
The moulds shown are used for the fire assays of lead, gold, and silver. A mould consists usually of a cast-iron block containing conical or hemispherical cavities, into which the molten assays are poured. On solidification the material is tipped out of the mould and the metallic lead detached from the accompanying slag, which, being lighter, remain on the top of the lead.

description: This is an old muffle furnace, supposed to have been used in some experiments on the cupellation of silver by Sir Isaac Newton during the period 1699-1727, when he was Master of the Mint. It has a rectangular iron casing, lined with bricks (the present lining is modern), and is fitted with a grate. The muffle was heated by charcoal or coke. There seems to have been no flue, and the lid must have been used as a damper. There is a ledge in front for supporting cupels, etc., and there are sliding doors to the muffle and to the ash-pit openings.
interpretation: supposed to have been used in some experiments on the cupellation of silver.

description:
The muffle, which is of thin firebrick, is inserted through an opening in an iron-bound refractory body, between which and the sides of the muffle there is space for the flames from a Bunsen burner to play on their way to the chimney flue on top. The opening is closed by two refractory blocks. The front ledge of the body is convenient for supporting cupels.
The Bunsen burner tube delivers into a round box, covered with wire gauze, above which is a grid consisting of a number of short tubes.
interpretation: The front ledge of the body is convenient for supporting cupels.

description: This is a model of a muffle furnace for ordinary assay operations, made in sections for convenience of transport and replacement of damaged parts. The furnace is coke-fired, the fuel being introduced by the uppermost door. The draught is regulated by an iron chimney, which may contain a damper attached to the socket on the top of the furnace, and by a door at the bottom of the firebars. The muffle is supported by a small door, below the shelf in front of the muffle in such a way as to be surrounded by coke. Just below the shelf in front of the muffle is a small door, through which the fire may be stirred. The furnace sections are made of refractory material, strengthened by steel bands.

description: This is an example of the rolling mill used by assayers for rolling out the buttons of gold or silver, obtained in bullion assaying, into thin strips for further treatment. object_name: CASE SHOWING SUCCESSIVE PROCESSES OF GOLD ASSAYING
description:
The process of gold assaying comprises six distinct operations.
1. The portion of metal to be assayed is adjusted to an exact weight by cutting and filing (see Specimen A). Such accurately weighed portions of alloy are wrapped, together with definite weights of pure silver (B), in packets of lead foil (CC₁), and placed in order on a tray.
2. The packets are transferred to bone-ash cupels, arranged in rows corresponding to those on the tray, in a muffle, which is fixed in a suitable furnace and maintained at a bright red heat. The lead oxidises, and is absorbed by the cupel, together with the copper and other oxidisable metals present, while the silver and gold remain behind in the form of a button (D), which may also contain metals of the platinum group.
3. These buttons are hammered out into discs (E), which after being annealed are rolled into thin strips (F), and these are again annealed and rolled into loose coils, or “cornets” (G). The annealing is carried out in an iron tray.
4. The cornets are placed in small perforated platinum cups, arranged in a perforated tray of the same metal. The whole is then introduced into a platinum boiler, containing boiling nitric acid of specific gravity 1·26, in which it is allowed to remain for 15 mins.; it is then transferred to a similar boiler with acid of specific gravity 1·31. The silver is removed by the action of the acid, and the gold remains in a dark brown spongy state (H). The tray is then removed, washed in a boiler containing boiling distilled water, removed and allowed to dry.
5. The gold spongy mass, which retains the original form of the cornet, is rendered coherent by annealing at a dull red heat. This is done by introducing the platinum tray into the muffle. The cornets then assume the appearance of (I).
6. The final operation consists in weighing the cornet on a special “assay” balance. The weights employed bear a decimal relation to the original weight of metal taken for assay. The percentage of gold, or more usually the “fineness,” is at once indicated without calculation. The weighings are made on the same balance as that used in the first process.

description: This balance, which was designed by the late George Hogarth Makins, Esq., represents an early and successful attempt to secure greater sensitivity in balances used for the weighing of small quantities of the precious metals obtained in the assay of ores and bullion. The weight of the beam of this balance, with all its fixed appendages, is only 103 grains. The set of gold assay weights are graduated in carats.

description: This system of weights is designed to obviate the necessity of calculation of results in the fire assays of gold and silver ores. The assay ton weight is made to contain the same number of milligrammes as there are troy ounces of gold per long ton of 2,240 lb. of ore. The "long" assay ton weight is 32,666 mg. If this weight is corresponding to the assay ton of ore be taken for assay, each milligramme of gold obtained represents 1 troy oz. of gold per ton, and is thus read off directly in ounces per ton without calculation. The box contains multiples and sub-multiples of the assay ton for use in the assay of poor or rich ores respectively.
