collection: APPARATUS USED IN THE GAY-LUSSAC ASSAY OF SILVER BULLION
object_name: APPARATUS USED IN THE GAY-LUSSAC ASSAY OF SILVER BULLION
description:
This exhibit comprises the chief appliances required for the assay. The process was introduced at the Royal Mint in 1871, and is in use in substantially the same form at the present day. The method consists in precipitating the silver from a solution of a known weight of the alloy to be assayed by means of standard solutions of sodium chloride (common salt). A definite volume of a strong solution of salt is first added, sufficient to precipitate almost the whole of the silver present. The bottle containing the assay is then vigorously shaken, to coagulate the precipitate and to facilitate settlement. Small quantities of "decimal" salt solution, which is one-tenth of the strength of the "standard" solution, are then added to the clear supernatant liquid to precipitate the residual silver. These additions of weak solution are continued until either no "cloud," or a very slight one, is produced. This indicates the conclusion of the operation. The quantity of silver present can be deduced from the amount of salt solution used. Since all these operations are carried out under standard conditions for any particular alloy, the percentage of the alloy is usually determined by reference to a table. The following is a full list of apparatus used:—
(1) Copper cistern, lined with resinous cement, to contain the normal solution of salt.
(2) Funnel for use in filling the cistern.
(3) Pipette of 100 c.c. for use with normal solution.
(4) Pipette for use with decimal salt solution.
(5) Pipette for use with decimal silver solution (if required).
(6) Cage for conveying bottles to the shaking apparatus.
(7) Shaking apparatus, with 10 bottles in position for use.
(8) Dark case for bottle containing decimal silver solution (to protect from sunlight).
(9) Hollow pillar, with sponge for absorbing the excess of liquid from the pipette used for the first addition of salt.
(10) Water bath for heating assay bottles during solution of assay pieces.
(11) Bellows for removing nitrous fumes from assay bottles.
(12) Whisk used for stirring the salt solution in the cistern.

collection: PIPETTES USED IN THE GAY-LUSSAC ASSAY OF SILVER
object_name: Pipettes used in the Gay-Lussac assay of silver
description: These pipettes are similar to those used in the Royal Mint, where practically all assays of silver bullion are made by the Gay-Lussac method. The pipette, No. 1, is fixed in a vertical position, and filled from below by a rubber tube from the cistern of salt solution. When the pipette is filled, the opening at the upper end is closed by the finger, the rubber tube is removed, and the solution is then allowed to run into the assay bottle placed below. The pipette, No. 2, is divided into cubic centimetres, and is used in the ordinary manner for the additions of “decimal” salt solution.

collection: SET OF APPARATUS FOR THE EGGERTZ COLOUR TEST FOR THE ESTIMATION OF CARBON IN STEEL
object_name: Apparatus for the Eggertz Colour Test for the Estimation of Carbon in Steel
description:
This exhibit illustrates the complete set of apparatus required for the test, and comprises:—
Balance for weighing the steel samples.
Box of weights.
Copper water-bath, with thermometer and stand.
Test-tubes and test-tube stand.
Graduated comparison tubes.
Ground plate-glass screen.
Bunsen burners.
Archimedian drill, for taking sample.
Hydrometer, for adjusting strength of acid.
interpretation:
This test depends upon the fact that when steel is dissolved in dilute nitric acid the combined carbon present imparts a brownish colouration to the solution. By comparing the depth of colour produced by a steel with that obtained from a steel of known carbon content, under similar conditions, the carbon in the unknown steel may be determined.
The test is usually made by weighing out 0·1 grm. of the steel and of a standard, and dissolving each in 3 c.c. of nitric acid of specific gravity 1·2 in test tubes, heated in a water-bath. When both are dissolved, the solutions are rapidly cooled, diluted somewhat, transferred to graduated comparison tubes, and the darker one diluted still further until the colours match, comparison being made by holding the tubes against a ground glass screen, or similar background. When the colours are matched the carbon percentages are directly proportional to the volumes.

description: This is an apparatus for the rapid estimation of carbon in steels by Stead's alkali method. The apparatus consists essentially of three glass tubes, of equal bore throughout, mounted vertically in a suitable stand. The centre tube is sealed at the bottom, and contains the solution to be tested. The outer tubes are drawn out at the lower end, and pass into bottles containing standard solutions suitable for comparison, one set away. In making a test, the centre tube is filled with the assay solution to, say, 20 divisions. The standard solution in one or other of the syringe until the depth of tint, as shown by the corresponding side tube by means of the solution is then forced up into the centre tube by means of the manipulation of the syringe. The standard and assay are then measured by means of the scale and movable pointer. The standard solution bottles are filled as required from a beaker of solution by use of the tapped bent tube and suitable manipulation of the syringe. The standards may be of different depths of tint, enabling better comparison to be made than would be the case with only one standard. It will be apparent that the apparatus is an adaptation of the ordinary Eggertz test for carbon, using the special solutions due to Stead. The apparatus, with suitably modified solutions, may also be used for the determination of copper in steel.

description: This apparatus represents a modern type of that shown in No. 142, and is designed for the estimation of carbon in steel by direct comparison of the colours of standard solutions and the solution obtained by dissolving a portion of the steel under test in dilute nitric acid. The amount of combined carbon contained in a steel is accurately determined by a combustion method, and a sample of the steel is dissolved in nitric acid, a solution being obtained in which the depth of colour is directly proportionate to the amount of combined carbon in the steel. A number of standard solutions can be made from such steels. To use the apparatus the depth of colour of a solution of the unknown steel contained in the glass tube is compared with the standard solutions. Another method is to use one standard solution, and dilute the sample solution until the shades of colour are exactly the same; the carbon content is then calculated from the amount of dilution found necessary.

description: This is a gas-fired combustion furnace, designed for the determination of carbon in iron and steel. The body is made of refractory clay, strengthened with iron bands, and rests upon a radial burner; it is supplied with four holes through which pass combustion tubes, of porcelain or fused silica, 28 mm. in diam. These tubes are surrounded within the furnace body by a cylindrical clay muffle, which ensures uniform heating of the tubes and lessens the liability to fracture. The burner is lighted through a hole in the front of the furnace body, closed by a clay plug when the furnace is in use. The porcelain combustion tubes are, for an actual determination, connected to an appropriate "train" of absorption tubes, to purify the incoming oxygen for combustion, and for purifying and collecting the carbon dioxide produced in the combustion.

interpretation: Designed for the determination of carbon in iron and steel.

description: This apparatus has been designed for the determination of carbon in steel by direct combustion in an electric furnace. The steel drillings are placed in a small combustion boat and inserted in the centre of the furnace tube. Oxygen, previously purified and dried by passing over soda-lime and sulphuric acid contained in drying-towers, is passed through the furnace tube, which is raised to a bright red heat, and the steel drillings completely burnt. The products of the combustion pass out at the other end of the furnace, and through the absorption tubes. Of these tubes, the first set remains empty as safety traps; the second contains chromic acid; the third, sulphuric acid; the fourth, anhydrous copper sulphate in the lower portion and anhydrous calcium chloride in the straight limbs; the fifth, dry calcium chloride in the top bulb and 20-mesh soda-lime in the bottom bulb for the absorption of the CO2. The absorption tube is carefully weighed before and after the combustion; the increase in weight represents the carbonic acid from the carbon in the steel sample burnt. The final tubes are filled with dry calcium chloride to prevent moisture from getting into the absorption tube during the combustion. Inv.
materials: soda-lime; sulphuric acid; chromic acid; copper sulphate; calcium chloride
interpretation: This apparatus has been designed for the determination of carbon in steel by direct combustion in an electric furnace.

object_name: APPARATUS FOR RAPID ELECTROLYTIC ANALYSIS OF NON-FERROUS ALLOYS
description: This is an apparatus in which the metal to be estimated is electrically deposited on a platinum electrode, the solution being kept in agitation by the rotation of either the anode or the kathode. The solution containing the metal is placed in the beaker A. A stationary platinum electrode is held by the clamp B and immersed in the solution. A previously weighed electrode is held in the chuck C, which is rotated during the passage of the current. The density of the current is adjusted to suit the particular assay under consideration. The difference in weight of the dried electrode before and after complete deposition gives the weight of metal present. Rotation of one of the electrodes, with the consequent stirring action upon the solution, allows the use of a relatively high current density, with considerable shortening of time required for the assay as compared with the method when both electrodes are stationary.
interpretation: An apparatus for the rapid electrolytic analysis of non-ferrous alloys, detailing its function, components, and operational method. It highlights the advantage of electrode rotation for increased current density and reduced assay time.

description: This apparatus is designed for the electrical determination of the neutral point in acid alkali titrations, and is also used in wet assays for determining manganese and iron by oxidation methods. The liquid under test is contained in the beaker, and immersed in the same is a calomel electrode (which maintains a constant potential) and a hydrogen electrode, the potential of which depends upon the hydrogen-ion concentration of the liquid. A potentiometer connected to the electrodes measures the potential, and hence the hydrogen-ion concentration can be calculated. When used for acid alkali titrations, the standard alkaline solution from the graduated burette is added to the liquid, which is kept thoroughly stirred by means of the motor stirrer, until the hydrogen electrode shows a potential corresponding with the neutral point.

description: This model represents a type of muffle furnace known as the "Colorado furnace." It is used for enamelling work, for heat treatment of tools and dies, and also for direct fusions of ores in clay crucibles. The furnace is fired with solid fuel, generally coke, which is introduced through the fuel doors in the sides. Two further doors being provided beneath the muffle for stoking, draught regulation, and withdrawal of ash and clinker. The muffle is of the "highside" type and has a large body of fuel surrounding it in order to ensure even heating. For convenience of transport the furnace is made in sections which are strengthened with steel bands.

collection: COLLECTION OF CLAY AND GRAPHITE CRUCIBLES
object_name: Collection of Clay and Graphite Crucibles
description: This exhibit represents types of clay and graphite crucibles used for the assaying of ores by direct fusion, and for the melting of small charges of metals. In the assay of ores, particularly of those of gold and silver, a small quantity of the ore mixed with suitable fluxes is fused in one of the forms of clay crucible shown, the valuable content of the ore being recovered in a metal button, while the remainder forms a slag. Clay crucibles are used in a similar way for the recovery and refining of gold and silver, etc., from such material as "Jewellers sweeps." Graphite crucibles are used for the melting of metals, such as gold, silver, copper, aluminium, etc., and for the making of alloys from these and many other metals. The crucibles shown, which are of the type known as "Salamander," are models of larger crucibles which may have a capacity of as much as 600 lb. weight of metal; such crucibles are heated in tilting furnaces, while the small clay and graphite crucibles are generally heated in pot furnaces, or in muffle furnaces.

description: This model represents a type of furnace often used in prospecting and mining camps for the assay of ores of gold, silver and tin. The furnace is usually fired with charcoal, or with coke if available, and the muffle is easily removable in order that the furnace may be used for crucible or pot fusions. The body is made of iron lined with fireclay; a fireclay tile, bound with iron and fitted with a handle, forming the top, this being removed for firing purposes and for inserting the crucibles, etc. Doors for draught regulation are provided beneath the firebox and the products of combustion are led away at the back of the furnace. The total weight of this furnace is about 130 lb.
interpretation: Represents a type of furnace often used in prospecting and mining camps for the assay of ores of gold, silver and tin.

description: This model represents a type of tube furnace used for "combustions," as in the analysis of carbon in steels, etc. The tube is heated by a coke or charcoal fire, the fuel being introduced and supported in the furnace by means of the two round holes in the sides. Heat is applied to the tube by means of the sloping roof of the furnace and the bottom of the furnace. The draught is regulated by the fireclay door in the sloping roof of the furnace, and the products of combustion are led away through the bottom. The tube in which the fireclay "boats" containing the material to be analysed are placed is generally made of some non-oxidising and fire-resisting material such as silica, or of some special mixture of fireclay.
interpretation: This model represents a type of tube furnace used for "combustions," as in the analysis of carbon in steels, etc.

description: This model represents a type of furnace used for evaporating acid or alkaline solutions of salts. The basin which holds the solutions fits into the top of the furnace, escape for the gases from the fuel being provided by the recesses cut in the bevelled top. The furnace is generally fired with coke and the heat is regulated by means of the fireclay doors in the front of the furnace, the larger door serving also for stoking purposes.
interpretation: This model represents a type of furnace used for evaporating acid or alkaline solutions of salts.
